The range of measured water quality parameters varied from two to seventeen. Excluding the study that collected data for 17 parameters (Singh et al., 2022), the average number of measured parameters was 3.4 ± 1.1. Twelve studies measured four or fewer parameters to determine the water quality of a water body. The most frequently measured parameters were temperature, turbidity, and pH, determined in 11 studies, followed by dissolved oxygen and electrical conductivity, measured in seven and six studies, respectively. Only two studies implemented software sensors based on machine learning algorithms for predicting water quality parameters that cannot be directly measured using physical sensors. In only five studies, data was validated by comparing the results with those obtained following a traditional WQM approach. While the hardware setup varied among the monitoring devices, the preferred microcontroller board type was Arduino (n = 6), and the data communication was performed via a Wi-Fi module (n = 6). There was no clear trend regarding the preference for cloud service; however, most studies (n = 12) make data accessible online. Regarding power sources, solar panel–battery systems were employed in 47% (n = 7) of the devices, followed by using batteries alone in one-third (n = 5) of the monitoring systems. Monitoring devices were primarily employed to assess the water quality of rivers and lakes, respectively documented in seven and three references. Almost half of the reviewed studies (47%) were implemented in India (n = 4) and Malaysia (n = 3). The rest of the studies were implemented in China (n = 2), Italy (n = 2), Australia (n = 1), Brunei (n = 1), Hong Kong (n = 1), and the United Kingdom (n = 1). 3.2. Citizen science Twenty-seven articles (citizen science n = 25, mixed scope n = 2) focusing on citizen science WQM were analyzed on monitoring approach, measured water quality parameters, periodicity of monitoring, monitored water body type, information communication method, country of implementation, and main challenges. Additional aspects that were assessed included the methods for validating the data collected by the volunteers, the training of the project participants, the collaboration with government institutions, the understanding of water quality by the public, and whether water quality data was reported to be accurate (Table 2). Ten studies employed more than one monitoring approach to determine the water quality of a water body; the three most frequent were chemical test kits (n = 16), followed by on-site probes (n = 7), and traditional techniques involving the use of laboratory equipment (n = 6). Only one study employed IoT devices (Diviacco et al., 2021) for citizen WQM (Fig. 3A). The five most frequently monitored parameters were nitrate (n = 15), phosphate (n = 14), pH (n = 13), turbidity (n = 12), and temperature (n = 9). The analyzed articles measured 4.3 ± 1.8 parameters on average, whereas ten studies measured more than four parameters to determine water quality. The range of measured parameters varied from two to nine. Download : Download high-res image (402KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 3. (A). Monitoring approach for assessing water quality parameters in the reviewed citizen science studies. (B). Communication approaches for sharing water quality results with the public in the reviewed citizen science projects. Abbreviations - IoT: Internet of Things, Micro: Microbiological, SBS: Smartphone-based sensors. More than half of the studies (n = 15) monitored water quality without a specific periodicity, although some followed a monthly (n = 6) or a weekly (n = 1) periodicity. Five studies monitored water quality on a single occasion. Nine studies monitored more than one water body, mostly rivers or streams (n = 16), followed by lakes (n = 12), ponds (n = 5), the sea (n = 2), and wetlands (n = 1). The preferred approach for communicating water quality results was the use of a web page or web platform (n = 21), and only four studies (∼15%) used more than one communication channel (Fig. 3B). The analyzed publications were conducted in 19 countries, with three studies considering more than one country. China, the United States, and Canada were the leading countries, with four citizen science projects implemented in each country. Although the authors from seven studies did not disclose the challenges associated with their citizen science project, 11 reported more than one problem. The primary reported challenges were measurement uncertainties associated with the monitoring methods (n = 7), issues related to citizen engagement (n = 7), sampling bias (e.g., lower sampling of non-urban areas or certain water bodies; n = 7), monitoring results not used by scientists or authorities (n = 3), and a low number of observations (n = 3). Data validation, either statistically or by comparing citizen-gathered results with professional measurements, was included in the design of 23 of the 27 citizen science projects. Similarly, 85% (n = 23) of the studies reported that volunteers were trained before monitoring water quality. Citizen-gathered data were described as accurate in most publications (n = 17), with five studies depicting it as inaccurate and five not providing an explicit statement on data quality. Government collaboration or funding was identified in 15 publications. Lastly, only one article evaluated communication aspects by testing whether the citizen science initiative improved the participants' understanding of water quality parameters (Araújo et al., 2022). 3.3. Water quality communication Ten studies that evaluated WQC were reviewed (WQC n = 9, mixed scope n = 1). Most references (70%) focused on the communication of drinking water quality. Marine and watershed communication was covered in two and one reference, respectively. Four studies assessed communication based on Customer Confidence Reports. Two publications focused on developing water quality indexes with visual cues that can be used to improve WQC. Lastly, public perception and expectations of WQC from a general perspective were evaluated in four references. The analyzed references mainly focused on WQC in North America (n = 8). Marine water United States Pratap et al. (2013) 4. Discussion 4.1. IoT-based water quality monitoring Existing WQMPs often rely on traditional monitoring approaches involving manual sampling and laboratory analysis, which presents challenges in covering entire catchments. The former approach results in low sampling frequencies, which provide only a snapshot of the dynamic nature of water quality parameters, potentially overlooking critical events like flow or contaminant concentration spikes. Technological advances in sensors and communication technologies provide an opportunity to shift from the traditional WQM scheme towards automated approaches (Yanes et al., 2020). Automated monitoring allows the timely determination of water quality without deploying experienced field personnel to collect and transport samples for their analysis, facilitating high-resolution data collection (Meyer et al., 2019; Pasika and Gandla, 2020). Integrating cost-effective sensor technologies into WQMPs enables high-resolution spatiotemporal monitoring, paving the way for establishing causal relationships between drivers and response variables (Bieroza et al., 2023). This capability allows the detection of subtle changes in water quality conditions, which can be advantageous for identifying unregulated wastewater discharges into a water body (Solano et al., 2022). Using low-cost monitoring devices can make WQM more affordable, especially for countries with limited resources, opening the possibility of using the available budget to increase the sampling points and improve spatial coverage (Miller et al., 2023). This approach provides real-time insights into the entire river network, facilitating the identification of hotspot areas, which serve as critical starting points for implementing intervention measures to improve water quality (Lofton et al., 2023). Automated monitoring has recently focused on developing and implementing IoT-based WQM devices. As depicted in Fig. 4, the IoT scheme generally involves data being acquired, transmitted, processed, stored, and delivered (Y. Chen and Han, 2018). Data is acquired using sensors, generally located in situ, which measure water quality parameters and provide input to a controller (Geetha and Gouthami, 2017). The controller can then either directly send or process and send the data received from the sensor to an online web service using adequate communication technology. Cloud services can store and analyze data and apply machine learning algorithms to estimate water quality (Srivastava et al., 2018). Lastly, the analyzed data is delivered to local authorities or other users via readily available communication channels such as a web page, text messages, or mobile apps (Shafi et al., 2018). Download : Download high-res image (243KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 4. Steps involved in an Internet of Things (IoT) water quality monitoring scheme. *Data can be directly sent or locally processed before being sent to cloud services. IoT provides multiple advantages besides delivering high temporal resolution data to end users at almost real-time speed. The costs of IoT-based monitoring are relatively low because it employs already existing communication infrastructure and cloud computing (Shi et al., 2019). The heavy computational loads can be managed through cloud services (e.g., ThingSpeak, ThingsBoard, or Amazon Web Services), requiring only a simple and low-cost processor on-field instead of an advanced computing device (Ray, 2016). Integration into the cloud also results in local devices being employed for performing simple tasks and remaining in a low power consumption mode. Additionally, it is possible to integrate machine learning algorithms into cloud servers to enhance the determination of water quality by predicting additional parameters or future trends based on the measurements of physical sensors (Alshehri et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2019). Another advantage of IoT monitoring devices is that they can be coupled with software sensors, which are virtual devices that employ mathematical models or machine learning to infer the values of water quality parameters without the need for physical sensors (Zainurin et al., 2022). The former enables the estimation of parameters that are not directly measurable due to the inexistence of dedicated sensors or their high cost. Multiple studies have discussed the development of software sensors for WQM based on the use of artificial neural networks (Foschi et al., 2021), random forests (Castrillo and García, 2020), multiple linear regression (Schilling et al., 2017), support vector machines (El Bilali et al., 2021), fuzzy logic systems (Zhou et al., 2022), and Bayesian networks ( Zhang et al., 2021). The systematic analysis revealed two studies incorporating software sensors into IoT devices for monitoring water bodies. Wang et al. (2021) employed an IoT device that gathered data from five physical sensors (total dissolved solids, temperature, electrical conductivity, dissolved oxygen, and pH) to estimate five additional parameters (nitrate-nitrogen, phosphates, nitrite-nitrogen, 5-day biological oxygen demand (BOD5), and ammonia-nitrogen) using a general regression neural network and a multivariate polynomial regression model. The estimations were considered adequate, with determination coefficients higher than 0.78. Pattnaik et al. (2021) developed an IoT device with four physical sensors (dissolved oxygen, pH, temperature, and turbidity) capable of determining BOD5 using machine learning algorithms. The system was tested on-field employing a K nearest-neighbor approach for BOD5 prediction, achieving a 0.92 correlation coefficient. Relevant examples of employing IoT devices coupled with machine learning to assess water quality have also been documented in other contexts, including water purification plants (Bhardwaj et al., 2022), wastewater treatment facilities (Sundui et al., 2021), and aquaculture systems (Manoharan et al., 2020). A limitation regarding physical sensors is that long-term in situ deployment can cause fouling, a phenomenon characterized by the accumulation of undesirable particles or microorganisms within the sensor that can produce incorrect measurements (Murray et al., 2020). From the analyzed references, three research articles indicated fouling problems with sensors on the monitoring devices. Turbidity sensors presented this problem in all identified studies, resulting in readings drift (Chen and Han, 2018; Trevathan and Schmidtke, 2022; Wong et al., 2021). Regular cleaning and calibration of the sensors are recommended to ensure accurate readings, with the maintenance interval dependent on the local environmental conditions. Devices deployed in water bodies with high turbidity or high concentrations of microorganisms will require shorter maintenance intervals to prevent fouling (Wong et al., 2021). The suggested maintenance interval for the devices in the reviewed studies varied between one to six months. Predictive maintenance algorithms can be incorporated into IoT systems to indicate when maintenance will be required (Sami and Khan, 2023). However, shorter intervals will result in a higher device maintenance cost as personnel must be deployed to clean the sensors. Ideally, the systems should be developed so sensors and other mechanical parts can be automatically cleaned without human assistance (Singh et al., 2022). The calibration of physical sensors must also be considered to maintain accurate readings. Sensor calibration was reported in 12 of the 15 reviewed studies, indicating the relevance of this process for gathering accurate data. Calibration should be performed using certified reference materials at intervals dependent on the specific sensor and the environmental conditions (Singh et al., 2022). Although sensor calibration was reported as a widespread practice, measurement validation was only performed on five reviewed articles, despite this process being essential to assess the reliability of the data. Measurement validation should be performed by comparing the results from the IoT device with those obtained by following the standardized methodologies indicated in local legislation (Martínez et al., 2020). IoT-based WQM devices should be designed considering the place of implementation. Monitoring devices must be robust and reliable to withstand changing environmental conditions, as deployment and maintenance may be complex, especially at remote locations (Xu et al., 2019). In addition to the environment, birds and other wildlife can interact with the devices, causing damage; therefore, the design and manufacturing method plays a significant role (Trevathan and Schmidtke, 2022). Modular and reconfigurable hardware can prolong the lifespan of devices and diminish the expenses associated with replacing damaged or obsolete components (Rahmani et al., 2023). Energy efficiency is crucial for IoT devices, as replacing batteries requires deploying personnel, leading to increased costs. Therefore, employing energy-efficient components and software is essential for IoT systems, especially those solely reliant on battery power. Using low-power wide-area networks such as LoRa (Long Range Wide Area), Sigfox, or NB-IoT (Narrowband-IoT) will extend the interval for replacing batteries (Olatinwo and Joubert, 2019). Selecting an appropriate routing protocol is also relevant for optimizing energy efficiency in IoT devices, as these protocols determine the paths that data packets take through the network. Recent studies have focused on the development of energy-efficient protocols for IoT applications (Chithaluru et al., 2023; Narayan et al., 2023). Integrating energy harvesting technologies into IoT devices such as solar panels is recommended as they can continuously provide energy to the system, thereby increasing its independence capabilities (Sanislav et al., 2021). The reliance on external cloud services and communication technologies can hinder the implementation of IoT-based WQM systems. While commercial cloud services offer multiple benefits, the proper functioning of IoT devices relies on the continuous availability of these services, rendering them dependent on external entities. IoT devices relying on external cloud services are susceptible to increases in overall operational costs if companies raise their fees. Hence, when feasible, the IoT system should use customized cloud services based on local servers (Jan et al., 2021). Additionally, cloud service availability and pricing can vary depending on the country. Similarly, communication technologies like Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and cellular networking (2G, 3G, 4G, 5G) exhibit significant variations in accessibility and network strength contingent upon the geographical location (Borralho et al., 2021). Therefore, the selection of communication technology should consider infrastructure availability, volume of transmitted data, transmission frequency, transmission distance, and power source (Xu et al., 2019). IoT devices should also be designed to handle different network conditions, such as weak or intermittent signals. The constant connection to the Internet exposes IoT monitoring devices to cyberattacks. Vulnerabilities can exist in any of the layers of the IoT architecture, requiring that multiple security layers are implemented to protect the devices, communication channels, and applications that integrate the system (Kuzlu et al., 2021). Security measurements may include using authentication, access control, data encryption, threat and risk prediction, and intrusion detection (Rekha et al., 2023). Artificial Intelligence can be incorporated into IoT systems to enhance the detection, prevention, and response to anomalies or intrusions (Samriya et al., 2022; Wazid et al., 2022). Additionally, blockchain technology can provide an additional security layer by guaranteeing the traceability and immutability of the collected data (Han et al., 2023). Recent publications on IoT cybersecurity provide a comprehensive overview of the prevailing risks and state-of-the-art mitigation strategies (Sarker et al., 2023; Tariq et al., 2023). An aspect that remained to be addressed in the reviewed studies was the suitability of communication channels for delivering water quality results to the intended end-users. While twelve studies (80%) relied on online platforms accessible through smartphones or computers, three required data access from a local computer. The appropriateness of the selected communication channels depends on the end-user's preferences and the information's intended use (Behmel et al., 2018). Online platforms and instant messaging services effectively deliver real-time information to authorities or institutions, allowing timely WQM. However, diversifying communication channels is crucial when disseminating information directly to the public, as individuals may have varying preferences (DeVito, 2016). Additionally, some populations may have restricted internet access, limiting their ability to access water quality results. 4.2. Citizen science for water quality monitoring One of the critical aspects of successfully implementing a WQMP is sharing the generated information with the public and promoting participatory practices. The European Union Water Framework Directive (2014. 2000/60/EC) states its success “relies on close cooperation and coherent action at community, member state, and local level as well as on information, consultation, and involvement of the public, including users”. Also, SDG 6B aims to “support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management”. Participative approaches come with benefits such as raising public concern, gaining better acceptability of the projects, and gathering local and expert knowledge (Brouwer et al., 2018). Nevertheless, integrating public participation into WQMPs has been challenging not only because there are no clearly defined guidelines regarding the stage of the program in which this participation should be requested but also because public participation can take many forms depending on the context, resulting in variations in the objectives, the scope, the participants, and the structures at the local, regional, and national levels involved (Behmel et al., 2018). Despite the challenges, public participation should be considered, as the lack of incorporation of participatory practices can result in WQMPs that do not reflect the public's information needs (Behmel et al., 2016). Within participative approaches, citizen science, which involves the public's participation in scientific research and knowledge generation, has gained significance in recent decades (Jollymore et al., 2017). Citizen science is a non-traditional source of information relevant to achieving SDGs (Shulla et al., 2020). Traditional data sources, such as government ministries or institutions, currently provide the primary input of water quality data but face limitations such as low monitoring frequencies, and consequently, information becomes quickly outdated (Fritz et al., 2019). A further concern is that data are commonly reported on a national or regional scale, and local spatial variations are often overlooked (König et al., 2021). Citizen science can potentially improve temporal and spatial data resolution, overcoming the previous constraints on water quality data (San Llorente Capdevila et al., 2020). The recent interest in citizen science mainly derives from its multiple advantages beyond generating scientific knowledge, such as raising public awareness, promoting more effective legislation, and directing public spending towards priority areas (Fraisl et al., 2022). Moreover, citizen science contributes to an increase in the scientific literacy of the public participating in the project (Phillips et al., 2018). Citizens may participate in either some or multiple stages of the scientific process. These stages may include the formulation of the research question (Parris et al., 2023), co-designing of the project (Clarke et al., 2023), data collection (Moshi et al., 2022), data analysis (Hoyer and Canfield, 2021), and results communication (Araújo et al., 2022). Despite the previous advantages, implementing citizen science for WQM faces multiple challenges. One of the most significant concerns is the potential for data quality uncertainties (Burgess et al., 2017). Measurement uncertainties were reported to be a challenge for approximately 26% of the reviewed studies. Some of these uncertainties can be attributed to the nature of the methods used for determining water quality (Cakmak et al., 2021; Moshi et al., 2022). Testing kits, used in nearly 60% of the reviewed publications, are usually based on colorimetric methods to readily determine the values of water quality parameters such as nitrate and phosphate. However, participants may experience difficulties interpreting the test results and deciding the concentration range of a parameter based on the color (Quinlivan et al., 2020). While on-site probes offer the potential to enhance data accuracy in citizen science projects, they also present challenges. A study performed in Hong Kong where citizens were given a Horiba U-50 multiparameter water quality meter revealed that some participants found the measuring procedures very technical to follow, and sometimes they forgot or overlooked some minor steps or guidelines given to them in training (Ho et al., 2020). Similar findings were reported in a study conducted in Myanmar, where simple sensors outperformed a high-end multiparametric probe due to volunteers' difficulty in troubleshooting technical issues with the equipment, resulting in data loss and periods of inactivity (Thatoe Nwe Win et al., 2019). Furthermore, highly specialized equipment will increase monitoring costs, which is only feasible for some initiatives. Previous findings suggest that the technology employed for citizen science WQM should be affordable, user-friendly, and capable of generating accurate results. IoT devices and smartphone-based sensors hold promise in this regard. However, the systematic analysis only revealed one study regarding IoT devices and another on a smartphone-based sensor. The IoT device, deployed on small vessels employed for leisure or fishing in Italy, could monitor seawater temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, and pH and automatically transmit the collected results to a database (Diviacco et al., 2021). The smartphone-based device was reported in a publication where students determined nitrate and phosphate concentrations in a river in China (Zheng et al., 2022). According to their respective authors, both devices provided accurate data. Apart from employing different technologies, multiple approaches can increase data quality at different project stages. The actions include volunteer training, validation with experts, peer reviews, the use of standardized protocols and calibrated tools, and the implementation of novel statistical analysis technologies (Fritz et al., 2019). In this regard, 85% of the examined articles either provided participant training, performed water quality data validation, or did both. The degree of quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC) varied significantly among the projects. While some projects relied on outlier detection alone, citizen science organizations like Texas Stream Team and Florida LAKEWATCH have established robust QA/QC measures to produce high-quality water quality data. Shared salient measures of these organizations include (1) on-site participant training with annual refresher sessions, (2) implementation of standard operating procedures for field and laboratory analysis, (3) continuous evaluations of data precision and accuracy, (4) and comparison studies with professional organizations (Albus et al., 2020; Hoyer and Canfield, 2021). Appropriate training can ensure that the participants have the required information to produce data of sufficient quality. However, mandatory training may lower participation rates (Peeters et al., 2022). Therefore, training needs to be dynamic, accessible, inclusive, and appealing to achieve a good level of commitment from volunteers (Pérez-Belmont et al., 2019). Training can be provided using different approaches, such as videos, step-by-step guides, or workshops (Shupe, 2017; George et al., 2021; Hegarty et al., 2021). Training may also involve testing the skills of the volunteers by comparing their measurements with those taken by instructors and providing customized feedback on how to improve measurements (Shupe, 2017) or requiring participants to pass a test before being able to collect water quality data (Quinlivan et al., 2020). In addition to the specific project training, academic institutions such as Cornell University and University College London currently offer citizen science certifications that can help improve participants’ scientific knowledge and skills. Standardized procedures can also improve data quality by ensuring reproducibility, consistency, and comparability of measurements. Standardized procedures are particularly relevant to enhancing the scientific community and decision-makers' acceptance of the monitoring results (Brown and Williams, 2019). Citizen science projects can either develop their procedures or adhere to those established by other initiatives or organizations. Through its FreshWater Watch global project, international organizations such as Earthwatch Europe have established standardized measurement protocols, training, and quality control processes to increase the comparability of citizen-gathered data worldwide (Earthwatch Europe, 2023a). Another challenge, reported in 26% of the reviewed studies, is related to the engagement of citizen scientists. Reported issues include failing to recruit a sufficient number of participants (Diviacco et al., 2021), difficulties maintaining volunteer engagement (Biraghi et al., 2022; George et al., 2021; Peeters et al., 2022; Zheng et al., 2017), low levels of interest (Quinlivan et al., 2020), and time-consuming processes needed for engagement (Thornhill et al., 2018). In this regard, understanding participant motivations is fundamental to (1) developing tasks that align with multiple interests, (2) ensuring that these tasks meet participant expectations, (3) allowing for continuous volunteer feedback, and (4) integrating citizen scientists into co-design processes in the project (Fraisl et al., 2022). Motivation depends on the context, varies among participants, and may change over time. However, it has been reported that one of the citizen scientists' main motivations is to contribute towards environmental preservation (Jollymore et al., 2017; Lopez, 2021; Shupe, 2017). Thus, communicating how their participation contributes to this goal is essential to prevent participants' disappointment (Jollymore et al., 2017). Sustained participation will require developing projects considering participants' interests and designating staff to education, communication, and engagement activities (Peeters et al., 2022). Establishing partnerships with organizations or academic institutions can also improve the project's reach (George et al., 2021). While deficiencies in the project design may cause engagement issues, some contexts can be particularly challenging for implementing successful citizen science projects. As noted by Fraisl et al. (2022), in places that are affected by a high degree of social inequality, these initiatives may only result in the engagement of certain parts of society, excluding either or both citizens with low income and individuals belonging to underrepresented groups. In these situations, it is essential to implement strategies to enhance the participation of these groups. Providing economic incentives has proved successful in increasing and maintaining engagement (Zheng et al., 2017) and may be necessary to motivate the participation of low-income individuals. Spatial or geographical sampling bias is another concern observed in 26% of the reviewed citizen science projects. Sampling bias can be attributed to the project design as it mainly arises when volunteers are not assigned to monitor specific sampling locations. When participants are invited to self-select sampling locations, they often choose easily accessible areas or places of local interest (Bishop et al., 2020; Hegarty et al., 2021). This leads to more observations closer to urban centers and road networks. Volunteers may also prefer to monitor visually appealing sites, such as ponds in parks, over less scenic sites (McGoff et al., 2017). Additionally, a higher participation of city volunteers can lead to an overrepresentation of urban areas and an underrepresentation of rural regions (Biraghi et al., 2022). Project design can also lead to temporal bias or fewer observations. For instance, only 26% of the reviewed studies had a determined periodicity. When periodicity is not defined, volunteers may monitor water quality during their spare time, leading to more observations produced during weekends. In other cases, observations can be produced randomly upon finding polluted water (Zheng et al., 2017). Additionally, some projects integrate public events into their regular monitoring activities (e.g., monitoring campaigns with schools), resulting in a temporal increase in observations during the event (Biraghi et al., 2022). Geographical and temporal sampling biases are not entirely negative. Highly engaged individuals who frequently monitor a particular site are more likely to encounter abnormal events that can be undetected when using a higher spatial distribution approach (Jollymore et al., 2017). Furthermore, monitoring small local water bodies such as ponds, small streams, or ditches is valuable, as these water bodies are often overlooked by national and international legislation (McGoff et al., 2017; Thornhill et al., 2018). Lastly, it is relevant to consider that even though citizen science can increase spatiotemporal coverage and complement official databases in some instances, it is not designed to assume complete responsibility for WQM (Cakmak et al., 2021). Geographical and temporal sampling biases can be minimized through careful project design, collaboration with experts, and strategic sampling approaches. Defining specific sampling locations or constraining sampling areas can significantly reduce spatial bias while establishing a defined monitoring periodicity can address temporal bias. However, establishing spatial or temporal constraints results in a lower level of participation and, consequently, fewer observations (Jollymore et al., 2017; McKinley et al., 2017). The requirement to designate precise monitoring sites or sampling frequencies will ultimately be contingent on the project goals and should consider the repercussions for public involvement. When the project objective is to fill temporal gaps of an existing WQMP or validate data quality, monitoring points should match those used by professionals, as variations in sampling locations may impact the level of agreement between both datasets (Albus et al., 2020). Conversely, if the goal is to increase the spatial coverage or resolution of a WQMP, project leaders must select distinct monitoring points from those already monitored by professionals. Citizen initiatives should collaborate with government and academic institutions when establishing monitoring points and frequencies to maximize the value of the produced information. Coordination among stakeholders can facilitate the achievement of shared monitoring goals by distributing the efforts and necessary expenditures (Gradilla-Hernández et al., 2022). Securing participation when specific sampling locations and periodicity are essential can be challenging. However, some projects have obtained good results by integrating WQM into school activities or the participants' work. Araújo et al. (2022) incorporated middle school students into a citizen science WQM project to promote chemistry learning. In this initiative, teachers considered the participation of students in the project and designed the school year schedule to allow some of the project tasks to be completed during school hours, hence facilitating the project implementation. Another initiative involving a collaboration between the financial organization HSBC and Earthwatch promoted the participation of volunteer employees from HSBC by considering the project as part of their jobs (Pérez-Belmont et al., 2019). Nevertheless, applying the previous approaches in all contexts may not be feasible, requiring the project engagement strategies to be adapted to meet monitoring requirements. Though explicitly mentioned in only three studies, the underutilization of the results from citizen science studies on WQMP remains a critical issue demanding attention. This underutilization may stem from the perception that citizen-generated data is less reliable than the information produced by professional scientists. However, research has shown that citizens can provide valuable and reliable contributions of similar quality to those produced by professionals when adequate training, procedures, and methods are provided (Kosmala et al., 2016). Citizen science programs such as Texas Stream Team and Florida LAKEWATCH have relevant QA/QC protocols to comply with United States federal standards and have been producing high-quality information for decades, yet much of the information has remained underutilized (Albus et al., 2020; Hoyer and Canfield, 2021). Carlson and Cohen (2018) explored the relationships between citizen water monitoring and water initiatives led by the Canadian government. Their findings indicate that even though citizen organizations followed standardized monitoring protocols, less than half of them stated that their data is being used to inform government water policy. Furthermore, more cooperation was observed among citizen monitoring organizations than between citizen organizations and the government. The scientific value underestimation of citizens' data and the lack of effective communication must be assessed for the effective valorization of citizen science. Establishing partnerships among government agencies, scientific institutions, and citizen science groups is essential to designing and successfully implementing projects that fulfill shared requirements and achieve mutual goals (Agarwal et al., 2023). A topic that did not receive the required attention in the reviewed articles was evaluating the communication process in citizen science initiatives. None of the studies evaluated whether the general population understood their published results. Only one study tested whether participants understood water quality parameters better after the citizen science project (Araújo et al., 2022). Evaluating participants' understanding of the data they collected and its use is relevant for maintaining engagement (Lopez, 2021). In some initiatives, the transfer of information can be unidirectional from scientists to citizens or from more experienced participants to newly incorporated ones. The absence of a reciprocal knowledge exchange hinders the effective integration of contextual, traditional, and local knowledge, often recognized as valuable but surprisingly absent in many documented citizen science implementations (Jollymore et al., 2017). Lastly, it is essential to consider the channels used to communicate citizen-collected data. Most of the reviewed studies (∼78%) used either a website or a web-based platform to publish their results, followed by smartphone apps (∼11%) or social media (∼7%). While the public may prefer these channels in some contexts, communication strategies should be specifically designed for the place of implementation of citizen science projects. Communication channels dependent on the Internet may be unsuitable in places with limited access to this technology as they can exclude a significant part of the population. Moreover, only four reviewed studies indicated using multiple communication channels (Biraghi et al., 2022; George et al., 2021; Hegarty et al., 2021; H. Zheng et al., 2017). As discussed in the next section, employing multiple communication channels is needed to increase the likelihood that the information reaches the population, as some individuals may prefer one channel over another. Incorporating technological tools such as web-based platforms and mobile applications into WQM has multiple advantages, as these technologies can also be employed for data collection. Both tools can provide participants with a user-friendly interface to improve their understanding of the monitored ecosystem. Additionally, they can increase data quality as measurements can be georeferenced and timestamped before being captured into a server (Biraghi et al., 2022; George et al., 2021). These applications should be able to function offline to capture information in remote rural areas with low or non-existent internet connectivity (Cakmak et al., 2021). However, centering the project around these tools may decrease participation in contexts with reduced technological accessibility, requiring a mixed approach in which printed materials are used (US General Services Administration, 2023). Communication of citizen-collected data can be further improved by increasing the visibility of the initiative. Visibility can be enhanced through collaboration with widely recognized organizations or government agencies, allowing participants to use existing communication platforms to disseminate their findings to the public. Multiple citizen science initiatives publish their results in Earthwatch Europe's FreshWater Watch web platform, making their results available to people worldwide (Earthwatch Europe, 2023b). However, data quality concerns continue to hinder citizen science data communication by government institutions (de Sherbinin et al., 2021). Citizen scientists should collaborate closely with government agencies and the scientific community to establish consensus protocols and the quality standards needed to enable their data to be reported alongside official data (Fritz et al., 2019). 4.3. Water quality communication WQC, like any other form of communication, should follow a process. In general terms, communication is a two-way process in which a sender encodes a message that is transmitted through one or more channels to a receiver which decodes and interprets the message; where message interpretation is influenced by the context and can be affected by noise (DeVito, 2016). Effective communication involves clear messages being delivered using appropriate platforms, designed to target diverse audiences, and shared by trusted individuals (Hyland-Wood et al., 2021). Efficient communication is essential when sharing the results of WQMPs, as these are the indicators stakeholders use to evaluate the efficiency of management strategies (Behmel et al., 2018). One of the main challenges affecting WQC is the low message clarity produced by the complex coding of information. This issue has been identified in Customer Confidence Reports (CCR), which are water quality reports that community water systems or water utilities must provide each year to citizens in the United States. These reports contain information about the water source, regulated contaminants found in water, and potential health effects associated with those contaminants (US EPA, 2023a). Studies evaluating CCR readability have consistently found that these reports are difficult to read, requiring a specialized reading level. For instance, Nicholas and Vedachalam (2021) assessed the readability of 243 CCR distributed across the United States in 2020 using the Flesch Reading Ease Score (FRES), a tool widely employed to measure the complexity of a document and the difficulty of reading it. The FRES returns a value of 0 if the text is practically unreadable and 100 if it is easy to read (Flesch, 1948). The average CCR readability was 7.46, indicating that the documents require the reading level of a university graduate. Similar results were previously observed by Roy et al. (2015), who evaluated 30 CCR issued from 2011 to 2013 and found an average FRES of 36.35, corresponding to a university reading level. Providing the public with water quality information with a complexity like that found in university-level reading materials could create barriers for a substantial portion of the population. For instance, 48% of individuals aged 25 to 34 in OECD countries held a university degree or higher qualifications in 2021(OECD, 2022). This suggests that nearly half of the population within that age group may face challenges understanding CCR. Furthermore, comparing both studies shows that the readability ease of CCR has not increased in more than seven years, indicating that the topic has not received sufficient attention. Hence, the public keeps receiving information that can only be adequately interpreted by some individuals rather than being accessible to all citizens. Phetxumphou et al. (2015) evaluated the clarity of message communication of United States CCR by using the CDC's Clear Communication Index, a tool created to develop and assess public communication materials. This index evaluates the material in seven different areas using 20 items to provide an overall score from 0 to 100, where 100 represents complete clarity and 90 or higher is a passing score (CDC, 2019). All the assessed CCR obtained scores lower than the passing score, and the overall score across CCR was 50 ± 14. Based on the results, the authors concluded that a large proportion of the public will probably not understand the message provided by the CCR, and hence, they will not know the degree to which local water is safe to drink. Considering the preceding findings, an effort must be made to improve the clarity of water quality information. The public requires aid in interpreting water quality data to understand the risks of deviations in a particular parameter and the overall risks associated with using their water (Brouwer et al., 2020). Additionally, citizens must understand the available information to assess whether the designated authorities manage their water efficiently. The comprehension of water quality empowers citizens to instigate interventions from authorities as needed. The overall clarity of the transmitted information can be enhanced by implementing clear communication guidelines in water quality reports, such as the CDC's Clear Communication Index. According to some recommendations of the CDC's Clear Communication Index, documents should (1) contain one main message statement located at the beginning of the material and emphasized with visual cues (e.g., bolds, font size, color) to draw the attention from the reader; (2) have images or graphs that support the main message; (3) include one or more calls to action for the audience even when the purpose is to inform; (4) use active voice and words that are understood by the audience; (5) present information in an organized way using headings and lists when needed; (6) provide authoritative sources of information and recognize uncertainty; (7) present numbers that the main audience uses (avoid using scientific notation or very large or small numbers by adjusting measurement unit scale); (8) always explain what the numbers mean; and (9) present and explain associated risks (CDC, 2019). Another strategy to increase message clarity when presenting water quality information to the public is developing communication tools such as water quality indices (Ewaid et al., 2020; Woodward et al., 2021). These indices generally summarize water quality into a single number, allowing non-experts to quickly understand the status of water without the need to review each monitored parameter separately and try to interpret the units in which results are presented (Casillas-García et al., 2021; Fernández del Castillo et al., 2022). Indices are often used to report the water quality of water bodies and can serve as tools for stakeholders to evaluate the government's management of a water source once the results of a WQMP are obtained (Kachroud et al., 2019). While a single index can provide a general overview, employing multiple indices tailored to specific aspects of water quality, such as heavy metal or microbiological contamination, can offer more detailed insights into the types of pollution present (Haghnazar et al., 2022; Karaouzas et al., 2021). Visual aids such as color-coded scales can further enhance the public's understanding of these indices (Cham et al., 2020). One innovative approach is a graphical index developed by Sakai et al. (2018) that visualizes water quality using a heart shape, where a perfect heart represents clean water, and a fragmented heart indicates pollution. This index is expected to raise public awareness of water quality issues and facilitate community engagement. However, further research is needed to evaluate its effectiveness. A second issue with WQC concerns the selection of communication channels for message delivery. Dunn et al. (2014) identified that despite water quality information being reported annually by water suppliers in British Columbia, the public often remains unaware of its existence or does not know where to find it. Another study by Ochoo et al. (2017) in Newfoundland found a disconnection between public perception and actual water quality, suggesting that information was not disseminated appropriately. Prior research indicates that the mere publication of information is inadequate; it is imperative to ascertain the favored communication channels within each social context and tailor communication strategies accordingly. Behmel et al. (2018) performed a study to identify the knowledge needs, concerns, and preferred modes of communication on water quality and quantity from the public of two distinct watersheds in Quebec. Researchers found that the communication channel preferences diverged among the population and changed between watersheds. Citizens of the first watershed mostly preferred interactive maps, followed by municipal websites and notice boards. Citizens from the second watershed preferred interactive maps, followed by municipal websites and social media sites. The least preferred communication channels were special bulletins and television news for the first watershed and scientific papers and television news for the second watershed. Similarly, a study performed by Brouwer et al. (2020) in the Netherlands found that most citizens preferred water quality data to be offered via a website and that data were presented in different layers, allowing interested individuals to navigate from a general water quality summary to information about each parameter. Previous studies have shown that the public prefers to access information online through digital platforms. These platforms are valuable for achieving effective communication because they allow the information to be displayed interactively and using visual aids, which can be advantageous when communicating a topic such as water quality, where usually multiple parameters are reported simultaneously (Cham et al., 2020). Platforms may allow users to summarize data using charts, review data in a georeferenced way, or perform statistical analyses. Additionally, online platforms can communicate water quality indices alongside parameters to enhance the public's comprehension of water quality. Table 4 provides examples of platforms that communicate water quality to the public at different spatial levels. Table 4. Examples of digital platforms for water quality communication. Platform name Level Purpose Reference State of Bathing Waters International Provide information about coastal and inland bathing water locations and their quality within the European Union. European Environment Agency (2022) National Water Dashboard National Provide real-time stream, lake, and reservoirs, precipitation, and groundwater information from United States Geological Survey observation stations across the country. (U.S. Geological Survey, 2023) LAWA River Quality National Present river water quality information for multiple monitoring points throughout New Zealand. (Land, 2023) Protecting Florida Together Water Quality Status Map State Deliver water quality information of multiple water bodies located in Florida. Additionally, the map showcases ongoing restoration projects that are relevant to water quality issues. (Protecting Florida Together, 2023) Chesapeake Bay Watershed Data Dashboard Watershed Consolidate and provide accessibility within a single platform to information that can be used to guide watershed restoration efforts. (Lower Mississippi-Gulf Water Science Center, 2019) Decision support systems (DSS) can also be implemented within a digital platform. These systems aim to assist decision-making by harnessing data from different sources to provide objective advice and background support on solving complex problems (Zhai et al., 2020). DSS can also serve as a mechanism for transparency, as users can replicate the decision procedure and assess the decisions regarding feasibility, strength, and robustness (McIntosh et al., 2011). However, as discussed by Walling and Vaneeckhaute (2020), the effective implementation of DSS remains complex as there are challenges associated with (1) stakeholders’ participation, identification, and fulfillment of their expectations; (2) the selection and implementation of the models within the system; and (3) the system design in terms of the user interaction to obtain relevant results. Digital platforms can also be used to promote public engagement. Public engagement in government affairs can take multiple forms, ranging from only requesting feedback on the published information to seeking a sustained dialog to achieve consensual solutions to significant challenges (Bertot et al., 2010). Digital platforms can serve to fulfill both purposes. Platforms should not only function as channels to convey the status of a water body but also as systems that welcome and disseminate water quality data gathered by citizens, as well as proposals aimed at enhancing water quality and its communication. However, it is essential to consider that WQC should use more than just a single channel to reach the public because there are population groups that may not be interested in using digital platforms, do not have access to them, or prefer other communication channels. Therefore, it is vital to identify the preferred channels in the geographical context where water quality is being communicated and adapt the communication strategy to employ multiple channels (e.g., social media, newspapers, notice boards) to reach most of the population. Lastly, a third issue with WQC is the lack of bi-directionality or feedback. Evans and Carpenter (2019) studied how water utilities evaluate the effectiveness of CCR in terms of consumer understanding, engagement, and shaping water quality perceptions. The authors found that from 238 water utilities distributed across the United States, about 55% did not track consumer engagement or understanding of the CCR, 68% did not monitor consumer perceptions about water quality, and 46% did not use any methods to understand what information the public would like in their reports. Previous data emphasizes the need for incorporating mechanisms to receive or gather public feedback. Surveys or follow-up calls can be employed to evaluate public perceptions and their needs in terms of communication. A two-way communication is essential to evaluate the effectiveness of WQC and prevent misconceptions about water quality. Receiving feedback from the public is valuable as it can help institutions improve the readability, clarity, understandability, and accuracy of water quality communications (Evans and Carpenter, 2019). Government institutions such as the United States Environmental Protection and the US EPA, 2023b and state-level environmental agencies allow public involvement by accepting public comments, organizing public meetings and webinars when proposing regulations, or accepting public reports of environmental violations. However, there is still a need to establish and evaluate the efficacy of mechanisms aimed at constantly receiving feedback from the public on how to enhance WQC. Fischer et al. (2022) suggested that to facilitate communication bidirectionality, scientists and communicators should train key agents to become citizen scientists who can communicate water quality to the public. Central agents can include political leaders, religious leaders, educators, or government officials, who can contribute to distributing information through different channels such as word of mouth or social media. Nevertheless, as discussed in the preceding subsection, citizen science WQM initiatives still require the integration of mechanisms to identify the communication channels preferred by the public and to monitor their comprehension of the transmitted water quality information. Integrating the former mechanisms and clear communication tools within these initiatives can transform them into a more valuable channel for WQC. 5. Future perspectives While IoT and citizen science offer valuable alternatives for monitoring water quality, these approaches must address certain limitations to establish themselves as robust sources of water quality information. The reviewed literature concerning the implementation of IoT-based WQM devices underscores the necessity for (1) increasing their robustness to withstand changing environmental conditions, (2) solving the need for regular cleaning and calibration of the sensors to prevent fouling and ensure accurate readings, (3) increasing the energy efficiency of their components and reliability of their power sources, (4) ensuring the continuous provision of cloud services, and (5) implementing robust security measures to safeguard against data breaches and cyberattacks and guarantee data traceability. Further advancements in the IoT technologies focused on WQM will allow the development of more robust devices at reduced costs, promoting the incorporation of IoT into WQMPs. Citizen science projects must surmount obstacles like (1) minimizing measurement uncertainties, (2) sustaining citizen engagement, (3) reducing sampling bias, (4) increasing the number of observations and collected data, and (5) establishing trust among scientists and authorities. Citizen initiatives should continue incorporating and improving their mechanisms to guarantee data quality. Projects should be designed considering that each context is different and constantly changing; thus, the initiative should have sufficient flexibility to adapt to changes in participant interests to maintain engagement. Citizen science initiatives should collaborate with governments and academic institutions to build and execute projects that meet shared objectives. These partnerships will play a pivotal role in elevating their public visibility, expanding avenues for funding, and shifting the prevailing perception of limited data reliability. In addition to preceding concerns, future citizen science and IoT projects should evaluate if their communication channels suit their intended end-users, especially when aiming to communicate with the public. Mechanisms to evaluate the effectiveness of WQC should be incorporated into the design of IoT and citizen science initiatives. Without integrating these mechanisms, the former monitoring approaches will continue to increase the amount of water quality data but not the public understanding of water bodies. While we did not analyze data-sharing practices among different users in this study, we encourage the adoption of FAIR principles (findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability) to facilitate the appropriate sharing of data generated by these projects among stakeholders (Wilkinson et al., 2016). Although multiple IoT and citizen science WQM projects have been reviewed, the extent of this study did not encompass citizen science and IoT implementations focused on using technologies like remote sensing or uncrewed vehicles, nor WQM projects focusing on groundwater, aquaculture, and agriculture. Therefore, further studies on the former applications are needed, which could offer valuable insights into common challenges and potential solutions. Similarly, this work considered only peer-reviewed publications, excluding project reports, websites, and non-academic works from which practical conclusions can be obtained, especially regarding citizen science and WQC. Lastly, addressing the shortcomings of current water quality communication practices requires the implementation of strategies that (1) enhance message clarity, (2) align communication channels with public preferences, and (3) foster bidirectional communication. Well-established guidelines such as the CDC's Clear Communication Index can be employed to make the information accessible to a wide range of audiences. Tools like water quality indices should be employed to facilitate water quality understanding. The choice of communication channels should be informed by research on public preferences within each context. Multiple channels are required to guarantee more extensive outreach across diverse audience segments. Additionally, communicators should be open to receiving feedback and incorporate mechanisms to promote public participation in water quality affairs. Enhancing the comprehension of water quality will enable citizens to evaluate the impact of their actions and the effectiveness of management practices implemented by authorities in safeguarding our invaluable water resources. A summary of the key challenges and recommendations is provided in Table 5. Table 5. Identified challenges and suggestions for IoT, citizen science, and communication in water quality monitoring. Area Challenges Suggestions Internet of Things (IoT) Improving environmental resilience • Design the device considering the place of implementation. • Use modular and reconfigurable hardware. Optimizing sensor maintenance and calibration • Integrate predictive maintenance algorithms. • Develop mechanisms for automatic sensor cleaning. Maximizing energy efficiency • Use energy-efficient components, software, and communication networks. • Integrate energy harvesting technologies. Ensuring the provision of cloud services • Use customized cloud services based on local servers when feasible. • Select the appropriate communication technology and design devices to handle variable network conditions. Implementing data security measures • Incorporate multiple security layers to protect the devices, communication channels, and applications. • Consider using AI and blockchain technology. Citizen science Minimizing measurement uncertainties • Provide appropriate volunteer training. • Establish robust quality assurance and quality control mechanisms. • Consider including automated monitoring devices into projects. Sustaining citizen engagement • Communicate effectively with participants and understand their motivations. • Design flexible projects that can adapt to changes in participant interests. • Designate staff to engagement and communication activities. Mitigating sampling bias • Establish specific sampling locations and periodicity during the project's design stage. • Collaborate with governments and academic institutions during the design of the project. Increasing the amount of collected data • Involve private and public institutions in the project to increase the number of volunteers and secure participation. • Apply strategies for sustaining participant engagement. Building trust among scientists and practitioners • Co-design of the project with scientists and practitioners. • Establish partnerships and effective communication mechanisms among government agencies, scientific institutions, and citizen science groups. Water quality communication Enhancing message clarity • Design communications strategies following clear guidelines. • Develop communication tools such as water quality indices. Selecting appropriate communication channels • Identify and use the preferred channels in the geographical and cultural context where water quality is being communicated. • Employ multiple communication channels. Encouraging bidirectional communication • Develop and implement mechanisms to receive and request constant feedback from citizens. • Promote participative approaches such as citizen science. 6. Conclusions IoT and citizen science pose promising alternatives for WQM, providing supplementary data that can address the spatiotemporal limitations of existing WQMPs relying on conventional monitoring methods. IoT delivers timely water quality information with high temporal resolution, allowing for enhanced environmental surveillance. Citizen science enhances public awareness and understanding of water quality while closing spatiotemporal monitoring gaps through data collected by regular citizens. However, both fields face challenges that need to be addressed. IoT WQM devices need improved robustness, power efficiency, data security, cloud services, and sensor cleaning and calibration methods. Citizen science projects must minimize measurement uncertainties, reduce sampling biases, increase the collected data, sustain participant engagement, and establish trust relationships with scientists and policymakers. Furthermore, scientists and practitioners need to focus on improving water quality communication with the public and develop projects integrating this aspect into their design. Paper 5:
- APA Citation: Ramos, H. M., Pérez-Sánchez, M., Guruprasad, P. S. M., Carravetta, A., Kuriqi, A., Coronado-Hernández, O. E., ... & López-Jiménez, P. A. (2024). Energy Transition in Urban Water Infrastructures towards Sustainable Cities. Water, 16(3), 504. https://doi.org/10.3390/w16030504
  Main Objective: To evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of using pumps-as-turbines (PATs) for energy recovery in water distribution networks.
  Study Location: Funchal, Portugal
  Data Sources: Hydraulic model of the Funchal water distribution network developed using EPANET software, simulation data from HOMER software, case study data from Funchal, Portugal
  Technologies Used: Hydraulic simulation using EPANET software, energy simulation using HOMER software, micro-hydropower generation, photovoltaic installation, wind turbine installation, pumps-as-turbines (PATs)
  Key Findings: The study demonstrates the potential of PATs for energy recovery in water distribution networks, with positive net present value (NPV) and economic benefits. The integration of PATs with photovoltaic and wind turbine systems can further enhance the system's efficiency and sustainability. Sensitivity analysis shows that the inclusion of PATs remains a cost-effective solution under various scenarios with capital cost multipliers for solar PV, wind, and grid purchase costs.
  Extract 1: "This study investigates energy recovery methods in water distribution networks with a specific focus on reducing water losses. This study was carried out in the municipality of Funchal (CMF), in a pilot area where a comprehensive study on the control of water losses had previously been developed (Figure 10)."
  Extract 2: "The overarching strategy was developed based on the Institute for Water and Waste Regulation (IRAR) Leakage Control Protocol to address and correct the situation described above. This protocol includes several essential steps, including the following: Establishment of district metered areas (DMAs): This means creating defined zones within the distribution system to facilitate the metering and regulation of pressure levels and flow rates in each area."
  Limitations: This study is limited to a specific case study in Funchal, Portugal, and the results may not be generalizable to other water distribution networks with different characteristics. Additionally, the study assumes that PATs can be installed without major technical or economic constraints, which may not be the case in all scenarios.
  Relevance Evaluation: The paper is highly relevant to the specific point of interest because it focuses directly on evaluating the use of pumps-as-turbines (PATs) as a means of energy recovery in water distribution networks, which aligns with the outline point of providing user-friendly interfaces for farmers to input preferences and expert knowledge into automated irrigation systems, using techniques like participatory design or user-centered design.

The paper addresses the specific issue of harnessing energy that would otherwise be lost via hydraulic systems for real-time irrigation management. The study provides valuable insights and evidence to support the use of PATs as an effective method for energy recovery in water distribution networks, contributing to the broader discussion on automated irrigation management systems.

The following overview provides a concise explanation of the study's purpose and methodology based on the information provided in the given abstract:

In this study, micro-hydropower generation and photovoltaic and wind turbine installation are investigated as potential methods for reducing energy consumption in water distribution networks. A hydraulic model of the Funchal water distribution network was developed using EPANET software, considering various parameters to simulate real-world conditions. The Energy Recovery with PATs section explores the concept of PAT systems and their installation in water distribution networks, including various modes of operation and efficiency considerations. The Energy Simulation section describes the use of HOMER software to evaluate the feasibility of energy recovery through PATs by simulating a microgrid system and optimizing its performance based on cost and efficiency.
