Paper 3:
- APA Citation: Wahlin, B., & Zimbelman, D. (2014). Canal Automation for Irrigation Systems: American Society of Civil Engineers Manual of Practice Number 131. Journal of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering, 140(7), 03114002.
  Main Objective: To provide a comprehensive overview of canal automation in irrigation systems, including its benefits, considerations, and control methods.
  Study Location: Unspecified
  Data Sources: Literature review, case studies
  Technologies Used: PID control, MPC, FLC
  Key Findings: Canal automation can significantly improve the efficiency, flexibility, and reliability of irrigation systems. Feedback control is crucial for ensuring accurate and responsive irrigation scheduling. Implementing closed-loop control mechanisms can enhance the overall performance of irrigation networks.
  Extract 1: "To simplify the design of controllers (which are usually linear) and to simplify implementation, most canal controllers determine the flow rate change needed for a check structure and then the gate position change required to achieve the prescribed flow rate in separate computations (algorithms)"
  Extract 2: "Feedback control. This section describes the mathematical procedures needed to tune controllers for the control of water levels, flow rates, and/or volumes within a canal. These methods use measurements of water level and/or flow rate to determine what control actions will bring the water level, flow rate, or canal pool volume to a set point value."
  Limitations: The paper focuses specifically on canal automation, which is a component of irrigation management but not the entirety of it. It does not delve into other aspects of real-time irrigation management, such as data collection and transmission, decision-making, or the integration of IoT and machine learning technologies.
  Relevance Evaluation: The paper is highly relevant to the point in the literature review that focuses on implementing feedback loops and closed-loop control mechanisms for real-time irrigation management. It provides an in-depth discussion of control methods used in canal automation, including proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control, model predictive control (MPC), and fuzzy logic control (FLC). The paper also highlights the importance of feedback control in ensuring accurate and responsive irrigation scheduling, which aligns with the objective of optimizing irrigation systems through closed-loop control.
  Relevance Score: 0.95
  Inline Citation: (Wahlin and Zimbelman, 2014)
  Explanation: The paper, titled "Canal Automation for Irrigation Systems: American Society of Civil Engineers Manual of Practice Number 131" by Wahlin and Zimbelman, provides a comprehensive examination of canal automation techniques in irrigation systems. It discusses various aspects of canal automation, including its historical evolution, benefits, implementation considerations, and control methods. The paper emphasizes the importance of implementing automated control systems to improve water delivery efficiency, reduce waste, and enhance the flexibility and reliability of irrigation networks.

 Full Text: >
"UNCL: University Of Nebraska - Linc Acquisitions Accounting Search within Login / Register Irrigation and Drainage Special Issue Paper Full Access Canal Automation for Irrigation Systems: American Society of Civil Engineers Manual of Practice Number 131† Brian Wahlin,  Darell Zimbelman First published: 03 July 2017 https://doi.org/10.1002/ird.2140Citations: 12 †Automatisation des canaux dans les systèmes d'irrigation: manuel de pratique N° 131 société américaine des ingénieurs civils. SECTIONS PDF TOOLS SHARE Abstract EN FR Recently, the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) prepared a Manual of Practice (MOP) on canal automation for irrigation systems. Formally referred to as MOP 131 Canal Automation for Irrigation Systems, this book focuses on the technical aspects of modernizing irrigation systems through the use of automated canal control systems. MOP 131 is an essential reference for professionals in agricultural and irrigation engineering, as well as owners, managers, and operators of irrigation water delivery systems. Canal automation saves water and improves the efficiency of irrigation water supply projects or of irrigation district operations. Recent technological and engineering advances now enable more accurate control of water deliveries throughout all parts of an irrigation project. Using information collected from irrigation systems around the world in conjunction with new advances in control theory research, this MOP examines how and when to implement canal automation within the context of canal modernization. In addition, MOP 131 provides practical guidance on other aspects of canal automation, including the modernization process, constraints, and concepts; survey of irrigation physical infrastructure; SCADA systems; control operation concepts; canal hydraulic properties; automatic control methods; verification of controller performance; and implementation of control systems. This paper provides a brief summary of MOP 131 within the context of the history and future of canal automation. Copyright © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. Background Canal automation always has had the potential to save water and improve efficiency of irrigation water supply projects or of irrigation district operations. Recently, there have been a number of technological and engineering advances in the field of canal automation. While these advances have been documented via conference proceedings and peer-reviewed journal articles, a comprehensive document outlining the state of the art in canal automation was lacking. The American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) decided to fill this void by commissioning the development of the Manual of Practice (MOP) 131: Canal Automation for Irrigation Systems (Wahlin and Zimbelman, 2014). MOP 131 was developed by the Task Committee on Recent Advances in Canal Automation (TCRACA) which was formed under the Irrigation Delivery and Drainage Systems (IDDS) Committee under the Environmental and Water Resources Institute (EWRI) of ASCE. Note that EWRI is an entity within ASCE that focuses on water resources instead of civil engineering in general. The TCRACA members gathered information on canal automation research and practice from around the world in their efforts to document the application of new technology to the progress of designing and implementing irrigation canal automation. The TCRACA was a truly international effort with researchers and practitioners from the USA, the Netherlands, Australia, France, Spain, Portugal, China, and Mexico all participating in the development of MOP 131. MOP 131 is designed to provide guidance on how and when to implement canal automation within the context of canal modernization but not covering the full range of canal modernization issues. The manual also provides practical guidance on some of the more routine aspects of canal automation. Note that while MOP 131 was developed by the cooperative efforts of eight different countries, it has not been formally adopted by the administrations of those countries. Historical Perspective on Canal Automation In order to plan for a successful canal modernization program, with measurable goals and objectives, that provides water users (irrigators) with improved flexibility, it is not only interesting but also very helpful to review how the science of irrigation canal automation arrived at today's technology. For purposes of this paper, a historic review will principally be from the perspective of the USA. A broader perspective would require more time and space than allowed herein. Then, as now, members of ASCE, working through committees of what was then the Irrigation and Drainage Division, which later merged into EWRI, paved the way for presenting and discussing improved operations of irrigation water supply systems. Their deliberations were published in 1968 as Automation of Irrigation and Drainage Systems which contained papers from a conference held in Phoenix, Arizona, in the United States (ASCE, 1968). A paper by the Salt River Project (SRP), a United States Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) project, discussed efforts to develop a supervisory control system for distribution canal operations that relied on new technology to measure gate openings, compute gate flows, monitor water levels, transmit data to a centralized operations center, and remotely move gates. During the same general time period, the California Department of Water Resources (DWR) was in the process of designing the United States' largest state-built water and power project to move water from northern California to cities and irrigators in water-short southern California. This project became known as the State Water Project (SWP). Power usage and power generation were to be key elements of the SWP along with the multibasin transfer of water. Optimizing power generation and movement of water, while minimizing power usage, required the development of an innovative canal operation strategy. The research developed from this project was presented in several publications from 1964 to 1976 and included topics such as hydraulic transients, check structure hydraulics, and computerized control. The research also resulted in the formulation of a computerized model of the aqueduct that simulated unsteady flow in the SWP. The USBR has the primary responsibility for the design and construction of water resource infrastructure for the purpose of providing irrigation water to irrigable lands in the western United States. As such, the USBR took the early lead in investigating ways of enhancing the operational efficiency of irrigation water supply districts (projects). While weirs, flumes, sluice gates, and radial gates were in common usage, the integration of electromechanical devices to make the task of water masters and ditch riders easier, more precise, and timelier, came about as a result of the USBR directing its researchers and design engineers to take a leadership role in the early development of canal automation equipment and procedures. Subsequently, the USBR published Water System Automation–a State of the Art Report (USBR, 1973). Concepts presented in this reference, for example that optimum operation will result only from proper control of the entire system, are still applicable today. ASCE's Irrigation and Drainage Division moved the technology forward in 1987 by organizing a conference in Portland, Oregon, called Planning, Operation, Rehabilitation and Automation of Irrigation Water Delivery Systems (ASCE, 1987). This included presentations by French engineers discussing their implementation of dynamic regulation in the system of Canal De Provence, NEYRTEC automatic equipment, and BIVAL for downstream control. Dr John Merriam introduced a definition for flexibility as being when the irrigator has control of the frequency, rate, and duration of flow. Only through maximizing flexibility can the irrigator maximize their productivity and economic return. Through the programs and projects of his employer, the World Bank, Herve Plusquellec was able to make presentations to many canal operators and water supply agencies throughout the world using a comprehensive state-of-the-art 35-mm slide presentation (Plusquellec, 1988). Mr Plusquellec was instrumental in bringing the concepts of improved canal operations and modernization to many who had previously not been aware of such concepts and ideas. This was followed by USBR's publication entitled Canal Systems Automation Manual (USBR, 1991). This publication was an update of previous USBR publications with discussions on the practical aspects of canal operation, control, and automation. The manual began with fundamentals and basic concepts, continued with more specific details, and finished with the more complex aspects of control theory analysis. The manual was divided into three parts that address three levels of readership: Volume 1–water users and operators, Volume 2–planning and design engineers, and Volume 3–research and development specialists. Understanding that to move the field of canal automation forward required that researchers and designers be able to model unsteady flow in a canal system, ASCE's Irrigation and Drainage Division undertook the task of providing a definitive treatise on unsteady flow modeling of canals (ASCE, 1993). Later, an EWRI task committee created a comprehensive and detailed review of canal control algorithms (Malaterre et al., 1998). Both of these task committee efforts provided for a meaningful advance in the formulation and verification of canal control theory and practice. Many of the ASCE/EWRI task committee members joined with EWRI in 1999 to organize and conduct a United States Commission on Irrigation and Drainage (USCID) workshop on the Modernization of Irrigation Water Delivery (USCID, 1999), with much of the focus being on current canal automation endeavours. While the above is certainly not an exhaustive presentation of canal automation research and development, it does provide a broad summary and a snapshot of how long water district managers have looked to technology to improve and enhance the delivery of irrigation water to their customers. It also provides a flavor of the approaches, technologies, and agencies that have contributed to the field of automatic canal operations. As pointed out earlier, the goal of MOP 131 is to bring all these past accomplishments together in a single publication that is up to date and useful to system operations personnel, planners, and design engineers. Overview of MOP 131 MOP 131 consists of eight chapters and a glossary. A brief summary of each chapter follows. Chapter 1: Modernization process, constraints, and concepts This first chapter in MOP 131 is probably the most important one. It provides a general overview of the potential benefits of irrigation canal modernization and discusses considerations for assessing whether or not an irrigation or water district should implement automation as it modernizes. If automation appears to be a viable component of modernization, then Chapter 1 describes how to proceed with the process of modernization. This chapter also provides a general overview of the potential benefits of canal automation. This chapter starts out by defining the concept of modernization. Modernization is a combination of technical, managerial, and organizational upgrading (as opposed to mere physical rehabilitation) of irrigation schemes with the objective of improving resource utilization (e.g., water, labor, economics, environment) and water delivery service to farms (Wolter and Burt, 1997). Such modernization investment focuses on the details of the inner workings of an irrigation project. Planners and engineers for irrigation projects frequently equate modernization with practices such as canal lining, piping, and computerized automation; however, such investments are often of low initial priority if one examines the steps needed to improve overall performance. Computerized automation is typically implemented in later stages of modernization, after basic needs such as flow measurement and accounting procedures have already been completed. Modernization is a process that sets specific objectives and selects specific actions and tools to achieve them over an extended period of time. There are no ‘single answers’ as to how and when to implement automation as part of modernization because of the complexity and variety of combinations of the water supplies (surface versus conjunctive use), water allocation policies, water quality, timing of flows, adequacy of the water supplies, topography, aquatic weed problems, soil types as related to seepage and bank stability, usage of return flows, types of existing structures, and so on. There are, however, some basic principles that should be followed to achieve a high level of success in designing, constructing, and implementing a canal automation project. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Defining potential benefits of modernization and automation; Defining incentives for modernization; Defining realistic/evolving expectations and costs; Assessing the existing system; Defining institutional and operational constraints as related to automation; Selecting the appropriate canal operation strategy; Developing a plan for emergency response/safeguards; Defining where automation fits into a modernization plan; Defining the typical sequence of actions in the modernization process. Chapter 2: Physical infrastructure Chapter 2 provides an overview of the types of structures and devices used for flow or water level control in canal systems. For each structure or device included, there is a photograph along with a discussion on the advantages/disadvantages, the power requirements, and the serviceability of the structure. In addition, the presentation includes a discussion on what measurements need to be made while using the structure. Only structures or devices useful from an automation perspective are discussed. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Working with an existing irrigation system. Decisions need to be made regarding whether to incorporate existing irrigation system infrastructure or to replace the existing infrastructure with new infrastructure; Conveyance system considerations. The type of canal automation that is physically possible and practical is dependent upon the physical characteristics of the existing canals and water allocation policies; Gates for check structures. A summary of widely available check structure configurations is provided, including programmable logic control (PLC)-based, electrically moved check structures and non-PLC controlled ‘automatic’ check structures; Instrumentation and measurement. A discussion is provided regarding instrument considerations that are common to canal automation including water level, gate position, and flow rate measurements; Pumps. Pumps are an integral part of many automation schemes that must supply or accept water at variable rates that can change from minute to minute without advance notice; Regulating (buffer) reservoirs within the irrigation system. Regulating reservoirs have been used successfully in the western United States to reduce canal spillage, simplify canal operation, and increase the flexibility of the water delivery systems. Chapter 3: SCADA systems Chapter 3 presents considerations regarding the design and implementation of a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system that will support the advanced automation of irrigation canals. This chapter includes discussion of design criteria, applicable technologies, installation, testing, and commissioning of the system. This section of MOP 131 focuses on the SCADA infrastructure itself and not on the control algorithms in the SCADA system processors, which is left for a later chapter. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Basic introduction to SCADA systems. SCADA refers to a broad and ever-changing spectrum of electronic hardware, computer software, and communications infrastructure that provides a platform for remote monitoring and control in a variety of industrial applications. In canal applications (or irrigation systems), SCADA system complexity ranges from simple systems that allow operators to monitor a few water levels or flow rates over a radio network, to large-scale, multiserver systems capable of automatically controlling large canal networks over fiber-optic and microwave communication networks. Whether small or large, SCADA systems can provide real-time monitoring; remote supervisory or automatic control; alert or emergency notifications; troubleshooting; and automatic data reporting and archiving capabilities; Basic SCADA system components and function. In simple terms, a SCADA system consists of a central base unit, which provides facilities for data storage, manipulation, and visualization. The base unit communicates with one or more remote units (e.g., at a canal check structure) through some communications infrastructure. The remote unit communicates with sensors and implements control instructions issued from the base unit; Control options in SCADA systems. Automatic control options for SCADA systems can be categorized into three basic groups: local control, central control, and distributed control; SCADA project considerations. A discussion is provided detailing considerations for SCADA projects such as system evaluation, building an integration team, system maintenance, and cost. Chapter 4: Control operation and control concepts Chapter 4 presents basic canal control methods and their intended operational goals. A brief discussion of concepts required for implementation is also provided. The limitations of each method are described in terms of the overall control strategy. It is important to note that the concepts discussed in this chapter are not necessarily mutually exclusive, because different concepts can often be used on different parts of the same canal network. Each concept has advantages and drawbacks and each fits better with certain overall strategies. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Introduction to the control of irrigation canals. In general, control for irrigation canals can be grouped into two categories: supply-oriented and demand-oriented. It is important to note that most canal control strategies include aspects of both supply-oriented and demand-oriented systems; General strategies for control of irrigation canals. A common approach to canal automation is to make gate adjustments at each site successively and then return to each gate to make corrections depending on the observed situation. These initial changes and the later corrections can be interpreted as feedforward and feedback control actions, respectively. The initial changes in settings to provide the new flows downstream are feedforward actions, while the corrections based on the actual situation are feedback actions. Remote control, where observations are communicated to a central control room and, from there, gate adjustments can be remotely implemented, simply allows the users to perform these actions more quickly, more often, with better timing, and with the ability to see more of the canal conditions at once. Automatic controls allow these adjustments to be made automatically. Automation allows control actions to be made more often and, in theory, more precisely. But fundamentally, these different approaches (manual/local, manual/remote, automatic) use the same basic strategies. Chapter 5: Canal hydraulic properties Chapter 5 discusses the hydraulic properties of canal pools and structures, as they relate to needs for canal automation. Since this publication is geared toward modernization of existing canal networks or systems, detailed design considerations are not included. However, changes may be needed to the infrastructure to implement new technologies during modernization, so that the system will allow greater flexibility and thus potentially improve performance. This chapter also presents methods for describing the hydraulic response of canal pools, particularly how water levels respond to changes in flow rate. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Design issues. Various design issues such as freeboard, canal lining, intermediate structures, and flow capacity are discussed; Canal structure hydraulics. Summary information regarding the hydraulics of typical weirs and gates used in irrigation canals is provided; Canal pool hydraulics. Each pool is unique in its response to changes in flows through control structures. Physical parameters that influence this behavior are longitudinal bed slope, cross section size and shape, length, and bed material. Concepts regarding flow conditions, changes in canal conveyance, pool volumes, and travel time of waves are also discussed; Resonance waves. Resonance waves and their influence on automatic control can be minimized using the filtering procedures discussed; Identification. Methods for determining important hydraulic properties of the canal pool are discussed. These parameters are crucial for controller design. Chapter 6: Control methods Chapter 6 presents control system fundamentals and control techniques that are used to develop controllers for water level or flow rate in irrigation canals. This chapter presents methods by which the control strategies discussed earlier in MOP 131 can be implemented via electronic devices such as PLCs, remote terminal units (RTUs), computers, etc. The intent of canal automation is to improve the operation of the water distribution system, which typically means better service to farmers. Canal automation is intended to improve some aspect of operations by performing controls that would be difficult to do manually and to enhance system monitoring and emergency responses. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Introduction to control methods. Various control method concepts are defined including control variables and control-action variables; Implementation options. Automatic controls can be organized in a variety of ways: local control, centralized control, hierarchical control, and distributed coordination control; Decoupling pools and structures. To simplify the design of controllers (which are usually linear) and to simplify implementation, most canal controllers determine the flow rate change needed for a check structure and then the gate position change required to achieve the prescribed flow rate in separate computations (algorithms); Routing demand changes through a canal. Routing water through a canal, also called feedforward control, can be done by using the time it takes a flow rate change to travel from the head gate to turnouts (delay times). Various methods for routing water through a canal, an essential control function, are discussed; Feedback control. This section describes the mathematical procedures needed to tune controllers for the control of water levels, flow rates, and/or volumes within a canal. These methods use measurements of water level and/or flow rate to determine what control actions will bring the water level, flow rate, or canal pool volume to a set point value. Details on specific feedback control algorithms such as linear quadratic regulator (LQR), H-infinity, model predictive control (MPC), and proportional integral (PI) flow control are discussed. There is also a discussion on combining feedforward and feedback control. Chapter 7: Verification of controller performance The users of canal automation want to be sure that the automatic control system will function in a way that is useful for their operations. Two essential questions must be answered. First, are the right processes being controlled? Second, is the automatic control functioning in an acceptable manner? This chapter discusses the process that control system designers and integrators should go through so that they can document a successful automation implementation. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Performance testing issues. This section deals with performance testing of automated canal structure logic; Performance testing with unsteady-flow simulation models. Simulation models are a useful tool for determining the potential performance of canal automation. Many canal automation developers routinely test control algorithm performance for even a single gate with unsteady-flow simulation. This allows the gate to be tested under a variety of flow and operating conditions; Performance measures. This section outlines concrete performance measures that can be used to evaluate how effectively a canal automation scheme is controlling the irrigation delivery system. Performance measures for both water level control and flow rate control are presented. Chapter 8: Implementation of control systems Chapter 8 addresses the practical implementation of canal automation as a project within a wider modernization program. The automation of an entire lateral or whole canal system is described, rather than just a single check structure, because the challenges and benefits are much larger. This chapter describes the sequence of required tasks, including the customization of control software, the installation and commissioning of the field devices and central server software, the progressive activation of control throughout the canal system, the measurement of overall performance of the new system, and the training of operations staff. Ongoing operational tasks and system maintenance are also discussed. Concepts discussed in this chapter include: Project initiation. The first step in any automation project is to determine the project objectives. These might include the improvement of irrigator service levels, water savings, and better control of water levels, operational cost savings, or rate of return on investment. Clear, quantified objectives help ensure success by aligning the irrigation district and implementation team and allowing for objective measurement of performance; Configuration and customization of software. Discussions are provided regarding RTU/PLC software, communications software, SCADA software, water ordering and demand management software, and network representation software; Commissioning. Commissioning is the process by which equipment, a facility, or a plant is tested to verify if it functions according to its design objectives or specifications; Control rollout and tuning. Once the commissioning of the SCADA system is complete, the next step is to roll out or activate the control system. In this section, rollout of control refers to the control on a network scale as it encompasses the processes involved in rolling out control at each location. Sometimes the behavior of the actual system may differ from what has been modeled initially. Hence, fine tuning of controller(s) may be required at intermittent stages; Performance assessment and acceptance. As important as setting the overall project objective is the measurement of the performance of the canal system against those objectives; Postacceptance operation and maintenance. Postacceptance operations and maintenance are an important part of canal automation. It is the analog of a routine maintenance program that irrigation districts generally undertake anyway, but includes new equipment like the software and new operating procedures; Training. An automated canal system requires that operators learn a number of new computer skills and adapt to a new style of operation that involves reacting to operational problems rather than simply implementing routines. This is not dissimilar to the role of a pilot when an airplane is operating in autopilot. The pilot must vigilantly monitor instruments and correct for unforeseen circumstances or deal with alarms; Manuals. In addition to the training, the irrigation district must be supplied with manuals for every component that makes up its system. Conclusions Irrigation district managers as well as state and federal water resource management agencies have for more than 50 years looked to technology to increase their effectiveness, improve their operations, enhance water transmission and delivery, and make their canal systems safer and more responsive. As the technology provided by the development and enhanced performance of computers made quantum leaps in performance, it was logical for the computing power of these devices to be incorporated into the control of irrigation canals. Beyond the power provided by computer technology, was the requirement for an entire array of associate technology that needed to be developed and adapted for canal control. The associated technologies included equipment to measure water levels, flow rates, and gate movements digitally as well as radio and fiber-optic equipment to transmit and receive monitored data. As each of these technologies matured, the engineers and researchers responsible for the research and development of canal control adapted these new technologies into their designs. As such, canal control has matured and become more technically rigorous. In a parallel way, the software needed to control canals also matured through the incorporation of new theories or mathematical models into improved control algorithms. What started out as remote monitoring and control with much of the decision-making left in the hands of humans, has now been refined to the point that automatic control of irrigation canals is a reality. What was lacking was an up-to-date, comprehensive publication that would not only assist irrigation district personnel but also the consulting engineer community with a practical source of knowledge on the worldwide status of automatic canal control. The professionals who were active participants in the development and implementation of automatic canal control joined forces to collaborate on MOP 131 in order to bring their collective expertise together in ways that would be useful to water resources engineers and managers around the world. The professionals that contributed to the preparation, review, editing, and finalization of MOP 131 are hopeful that MOP 131 is adopted by the water resources community as the definitive publication on the state of the art of automatic canal control, and that automatic canal control will make a substantial contribution to the production of food and fiber for a world that is facing unrelenting increases in the demand for food production with limited water supplies, while at the same time meeting demands to preserve our environment. Acknowledgements The authors of this paper would like to acknowledge the authors of the individual chapters within MOP 131: Charles Burt (Irrigation and Training Research Center, United States), Robert Strand (LemnaTec Corporation, Germany), Peter-Jules van Overloop (Delft University of Technology, the Netherlands), Bert Clemmens (WEST Consultants, United States), and Sumith Choy (Rubicon Water, Australia). These individuals' dedication and commitment to the MOP 131 made the vision of this document a reality.   Explanation: This study introduces a novel irrigation scheduling framework that combines three machine learning paradigms (unsupervised, supervised, and reinforcement learning) with model predictive control and multi-agent principles to design a precise irrigation scheduler for large-scale fields. The proposed framework offers several key advantages.
- **Accurate and computationally efficient soil moisture modeling:** The framework employs long short-term memory (LSTM) models to directly model the dynamic behavior of root zone soil moisture content in each irrigation management zone, while accounting for the time-varying nature of the rooting depth.
- **Management zone delineation tailored to agro-hydrological modeling:** A three-stage process with a k-means clustering approach is utilized to accurately delineate irrigation management zones. This process includes elevation and estimated soil hydraulic parameters as attributes, resulting in optimized management zones suitable for agro-hydrological modeling.
- **Enhanced computational efficiency of the mixed-integer model predictive control (MPC) framework:** A multi-agent MPC paradigm is adopted where decentralized hybrid actor-critic agents and the concept of a limiting management zone are employed to enhance the computational efficiency of the scheduler.

The application of the proposed approach to a large-scale field demonstrated its capability to achieve substantial water savings and improved irrigation water use efficiency. The proposed approach also allowed for the utilization of less conservative maximum allowable depletion (MAD) values, resulting in improved water savings and optimal crop growth.

Shah a Show more Add to Mendeley Share Cite https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conengprac.2024.105908 Get rights and content Under a Creative Commons license open access Abstract Amid concerns about freshwater scarcity, the agricultural sector faces challenges in water conservation and optimizing crop yields, highlighting the limitations of traditional irrigation scheduling methods. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces a unified, learning-based predictive irrigation scheduler that integrates machine learning and Model Predictive Control (MPC), while also incorporating multi-agent principles. The proposed framework incorporates a three-stage management zone delineation process, utilizing k-means clustering and hydraulic parameters estimates for optimized agro-hydrological modeling. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are employed for accurate and computationally efficient root zone soil moisture modeling. The scheduler, formulated as a mixed-integer MPC with zone control, utilizes the identified LSTM networks to maximize root water uptake while minimizing overall water consumption and fixed irrigation costs. Additionally, the learning-based scheduler adopts a multi-agent MPC paradigm, where decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and the concept of a limiting irrigation management zone are employed to enhance computational efficiency. Evaluating the performance on a 26.4-hectare field in Lethbridge for the 2015 and 2022 growing seasons demonstrates the superiority of the proposed scheduler over the widely-used triggered scheduling approach in terms of Irrigation Water Use Efficiency (IWUE) and total prescribed irrigation. Notably, the proposed approach achieves water savings between 7 to 23%, coupled with IWUE increases ranging from 10 to 35%. Previous article in issue Next article in issue Keywords Learning-based schedulerMixed-integer model predictive controlHybrid actor–critic paradigmProximal policy optimizationNonlinear programming 1. Introduction According to the United Nations, agriculture accounts for approximately 70% of the world’s freshwater withdrawals, with the majority of the water being used for irrigation activities (WWAP, 2015). However, with the global freshwater shortage crisis worsening due to rapid population growth and climate change, there is a pressing need for effective water management strategies, particularly in relation to irrigation activities, in order to address the growing freshwater shortages. Closed-loop irrigation scheduling, which utilizes feedback to provide crops with precise water amounts at optimal times, has been proposed as a solution for ensuring efficient water management in irrigation. In the context of designing closed-loop irrigation schedulers, machine learning techniques and model predictive control have emerged as valuable tools. 1.1. Unsupervised learning in irrigation scheduling To improve water-use efficiency in closed-loop irrigation scheduling, it is essential to consider the inherent variability in agricultural fields, which necessitates the development of variable rate closed-loop schedulers. A key aspect of designing variable rate schedulers involves dividing the field into distinct irrigation management zones, which are characterized as homogeneous areas with similar soil properties and cropping conditions. This zoning approach enables a targeted irrigation approach, optimizing the allocation of water across different zones. Unsupervised machine learning techniques such as k-means clustering (Galambošová et al., 2014, Haghverdi et al., 2015), fuzzy c-means clustering (Fontanet et al., 2020, Li et al., 2007) and Gaussian Mixture (Yuan et al., 2022) have emerged as valuable tools in delineating fields into irrigation management zones, utilizing attributes such as yield maps, topography, satellite photographs and soil electrical conductivity. Despite the reported effectiveness of current management zone delineation approaches, designing model-based irrigation schedulers for these zones presents challenges. A significant challenge is that existing methods do not explicitly consider crucial model inputs, such as soil hydraulic parameters, mainly due to difficulties in obtaining accurate field-scale hydraulic parameter data. One practical approach to obtain soil hydraulic parameters at field scale is to estimate these parameters using field measurements. Remarkably, the literature has not yet investigated the utilization of estimated soil hydraulic parameters for the purpose of defining irrigation management zones that can be effectively modeled using agro-hydrological models. 1.2. Supervised learning in irrigation scheduling Supervised machine learning techniques have been utilized to develop efficient and accurate agro-hydrological models, enabling the design of robust irrigation schedulers. Notably, long short-term memory networks (LSTMs) (Adeyemi et al., 2018, Agyeman, Sahoo et al., 2023, Jiménez et al., 2020) and feed-forward neural networks (Gu, Zhu, Jiao, Xu, & Qi, 2021) have gained attention in this context. Despite their success, challenges persist in these modeling approaches. For example, previous LSTM models (Adeyemi et al., 2018, Agyeman, Sahoo et al., 2023) predicted soil moisture at a single location within the crop’s rooting depth, neglecting the fact that crops extract water from multiple locations. An attempt to address this in Gu et al. (2021) involved training multiple feedforward neural networks to predict soil moisture at specific locations within the rooting depth, with irrigation schedules derived through a weighted average of the model predictions. However, this method, while effective, poses challenges for optimization-based irrigation schedulers, as integrating multiple neural network predictions significantly increases computational complexity and time. Additionally, the feed-forward neural network in Gu et al. (2021) has a limitation, considering only a single rooting depth and not accommodating the time-varying nature of rooting depth, potentially impacting irrigation schedule accuracy. The literature has yet to explore the development of a concise data-driven model using machine learning to directly predict root zone soil moisture content while considering dynamic changes in rooting depth. 1.3. Scheduling In a broad context, ‘scheduling’ involves determining the optimal allocation of limited resources to achieve a specific objective. Scheduling is a decision-making process aimed at optimizing one or more objectives, considering the ongoing processes and their interactions with the environment. The challenges of scheduling are prevalent in various manufacturing and chemical processing systems. Numerous approaches have been proposed to address scheduling problems in chemical process systems. For instance, dynamic optimization-based scheduler formulations, as seen in Flores-Tlacuahuac and Grossmann (2006) and Zhuge and Ierapetritou (2014), have been employed to account for the dynamic nature of chemical processes. Furthermore, insights from Subramanian, Maravelias, and Rawlings (2012) have facilitated the transformation of scheduling models into state–space form. Reactive scheduling (Mendez and Cerdá, 2004, Touretzky et al., 2017), robust scheduling (Li & Floudas, 2014) and closed-loop scheduling (Gupta et al., 2016, Subramanian et al., 2012) approaches have been introduced to handle uncertainties’ impact on schedule quality. Another emerging area is the integration of production scheduling and process control (Burnak et al., 2018, Zhuge and Ierapetritou, 2012), driven by the substantial economic benefits derived from a closer integration of scheduling and supervisory control. 1.4. Model predictive control Model Predictive Control (MPC) has significantly shaped control practice, especially in addressing constrained multivariable control problems. It operates by synthesizing control inputs through the iterative solution of finite horizon optimal control problems across overlapping horizons. Recently, MPC theory and methods have found application in addressing scheduling problems (Subramanian et al., 2012). Notably, MPC has been extended to scheduling-related domains like inventory control (Yi & Reklaitis, 2015) and supply chain management (Subramanian, Rawlings, & Maravelias, 2014). In the field of irrigation scheduling, set-point tracking MPC (Delgoda et al., 2016, McCarthy et al., 2014) and zone MPC (Nahar, Liu, Mao, Liu, & Shah, 2019) have been utilized to calculate irrigation schedules. It is important to note that these MPC-based irrigation schedulers primarily focused on continuous-valued inputs. However, scheduling problems inherently involve combinatorial aspects, requiring discrete decisions to allocate limited resources over time. For instance, in the daily irrigation scheduling problem, determining the irrigation time involves discrete decision-making. Recent research has shown that discrete-valued controls can be directly integrated into the MPC framework with minimal adjustments to stability properties (Rawlings & Risbeck, 2017). Consequently, this has led to the application of mixed-integer MPC to address scheduling challenges in various domains, including chemical production systems (Risbeck et al., 2018, Subramanian et al., 2012). In the field of irrigation scheduling, a novel approach, namely LSTM-based mixed-integer MPC with zone control, was proposed in Agyeman, Sahoo et al. (2023) to address the daily irrigation scheduling problem. Despite advancements in optimization techniques, mixed-integer MPC still encounters computational challenges, particularly in large-scale systems. Therefore, there is a need to develop techniques that can efficiently solve mixed-integer MPC problems within a reasonable time frame. In this context, the sigmoid function approach was employed to enhance the computational efficiency of mixed-integer MPC-based irrigation schedulers (Agyeman, Sahoo et al., 2023). Despite its success, it is essential to address its limitations, such as approximation errors and occasional challenges with poorly conditioned optimization problems. Overcoming these issues can be achieved by leveraging the current achievements of reinforcement learning in addressing complex problems. An additional under-explored aspect is the comprehensive evaluation of the real benefits associated with adopting MPC methods in irrigation scheduling. Despite the potential advantages, such as enhanced irrigation water-use efficiency compared to the widely-used triggered approach, a notable research gap exists in the lack of extensive comparative analyses between MPC-based scheduling and the standard approach. Bridging this gap is important for promoting the wider adoption of MPC-based schedulers in practical irrigation settings. 1.5. Reinforcement learning in irrigation scheduling Reinforcement learning (RL), a subset of machine learning designed for decision-making in dynamic environments, plays a pivotal role in addressing key challenges in irrigation scheduling. Applied to this context, RL has demonstrated its utility in handling uncertainties associated with weather conditions, improving robustness, automating sensor data acquisition, and calculating irrigation schedules (Chen et al., 2021, Ding and Du, 2020, Yang et al., 2020). RL has also introduced a new approach to solving complex optimal control problems like mixed-integer MPC (Vinyals et al., 2019). Various strategies, such as hierarchical structures (Masson et al., 2016, Wei et al., 2018), and hybrid actor–critic approaches (Fan, Su, Zhang, & Yu, 2019), have been proposed to adapt RL algorithms for handling both discrete and continuous actions inherent in mixed-integer optimal control problems. Despite these advancements, research on RL for mixed-integer optimal control problems in engineering applications remains limited (Xu & Lin, 2023). Furthermore, the application of RL techniques to mixed-integer MPC problems in irrigation scheduling has not been explored. 1.6. Scope of work From the above, it is evident that existing irrigation schedulers primarily focus on utilizing individual machine learning paradigms to tackle specific challenges inherent in the irrigation scheduling problem. Likewise, MPC-based irrigation schedulers primarily integrate one of these machine learning paradigms into their design. The potential advantages of harmonizing these methodologies have yet to be explored within a single irrigation scheduling framework. Accordingly, the main objective of this study is to propose a novel irrigation scheduling framework that incorporates all three machine learning paradigms and mixed-integer MPC within a unified framework. In the effort to integrate all three machine learning paradigms and mixed-integer MPC into a single framework, this work makes the following contributions: 1. The development of a three-stage irrigation management zone process that incorporates k-means clustering and estimated soil hydraulic parameters to delineate large-scale agricultural fields into irrigation management zones optimized for agro- hydrological modeling. 2. The utilization of LSTM networks to develop a computationally efficient data-driven models capable of directly predicting root zone soil moisture content while accounting for dynamic nature of the crop rooting depth. 3. The use of decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and the concept of a limiting irrigation management zone to enhance the computational efficiency of mixed-integer MPC for irrigation scheduling in agricultural fields with multiple management zones. 4. The demonstration of the effectiveness of the proposed scheduling approach on a real field. During this demonstration, a comparison between the proposed MPC-based scheduling approach and the widely employed scheduling approach is performed in terms of irrigation water-use efficiency and total prescribed irrigation. This paper extends the findings presented in Agyeman, Nouri, Appels and Liu (2023). In contrast to Agyeman, Nouri et al. (2023), the current work introduces a new approach that leverages LSTM networks to develop computationally efficient data-driven models. Additionally, this study employs decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and introduces the concept of a limiting management zone to enhance the computational efficiency of the mixed-integer MPC-based irrigation scheduler. Furthermore, the paper conducts a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed scheduling framework on a large-scale agricultural field. 2. Materials and methods 2.1. k-means clustering for management zone delineation In the context of designing efficient closed-loop irrigation schedulers, the process of management zone delineation assumes an important role as an essential initial step. To this end, this study proposes a three-stage approach for management zone delineation that incorporates k-means clustering and estimated soil hydraulic parameters. The resulting management zones from this approach are optimized for agro-hydrological modeling. A detailed explanation of the various stages is provided below. 1. Stage 1: delineation according to crop type. The initial step in the proposed approach involves creating uniform areas within an agricultural field based on the diverse crops present. This step is important, as irrigation scheduling is significantly influenced by the varying water requirements of different crops. Given the common practice of cultivating a variety of crops in irrigated fields, using crop type as a basis for the initial delineation allows the subsequent stages of the proposed approach to effectively address the specific water needs of individual crops present in the agricultural field. 2. Stage 2: delineation according to elevation and soil-hydraulic parameters. In this stage, the management zones identified in Stage 1 undergo further refinement into uniform areas by incorporating elevation and soil hydraulic parameter attributes. The inclusion of elevation information is vital for ensuring effective irrigation management, as elevation significantly governs water movement within agricultural fields. Similarly, soil hydraulic parameters play a crucial role in irrigation scheduling, influencing soil moisture dynamics and water availability to crops. Elevation information can be readily obtained at the field scale through methods such as surveying or utilizing digital elevation models. Nevertheless, accurate determination of soil hydraulic parameters at the field scale poses challenges. To overcome this, this study employs a computationally efficient offline estimation technique, as previously proposed in Agyeman, Orouskhani, and Liu (2022) and Orouskhani, Agyeman, and Liu (2022), for acquiring soil hydraulic parameters in this stage. In this offline estimation step, soil moisture and hydraulic parameters are simultaneously estimated by assimilating remotely sensed soil moisture observations into the Richards equation using the extended Kalman filtering technique. For further details on the estimation approach in this stage of the delineation process, interested readers may refer to Agyeman et al. (2022) and Orouskhani et al. (2022). The specific hydraulic parameters used in this stage include saturated hydraulic conductivity ( ), saturated moisture content ( ), residual moisture content ( ), and curve fitting parameters ( , ). After obtaining the elevation information and soil hydraulic parameters attributes, they are combined to form the primary dataset for management zone delineation. Due to differences in magnitudes between elevation values and the soil hydraulic parameter estimates, the primary dataset exhibits features with considerable variations in magnitude. Consequently, the dataset undergoes normalization to standardize all features to a consistent magnitude level. To identify the optimal number of clusters or management zones, the elbow method is employed. Once identified, clustering is conducted on the normalized data using the k-means method to obtain the distinct management zones. The choice of the k-means clustering method is justified by its efficiency in handling large datasets and its simplicity in implementation. A summary of the key steps involved in this stage of the delineation process can be found in Fig. 1. 3. Stage 3: mapping homogeneous areas to irrigation equipment resolution. Subsequent to the clustering in the second stage, the resultant management zones often display irregular shapes, presenting challenges in the efficient application of water using the field’s irrigation equipment. To overcome this, the management zones are refined by subdividing them into smaller, more uniform sub-zones. This adjustment aligns the zones with the resolution of the field’s irrigation equipment, enhancing precision and efficiency in irrigation application. Remark 1 While the k-means approach is chosen for its simplicity, computational efficiency and extensive use in management zone delineation, it is important to acknowledge that it does not guarantee the discovery of the optimal number of clusters (or management zones). This limitation arises from its tendency to converge to local optima solutions, a consequence of the iterative nature of the algorithm starting from random initial centroids. On the other hand, alternative clustering approaches, such as the Global Optimal Search (GOS) (Tan, Broach, & Floudas, 2007), offer the potential to overcome this limitation. GOS is more likely to converge to a global optimum, especially when a reliable initial guess for the clustering data is available. In situations where achieving a globally optimal solution is key, approaches like GOS becomes more suitable. The GOS method can replace the k-means approach in the proposed management zone delineation process in a straightforward manner. Download : Download high-res image (230KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 1. An illustration of Stage 2 of the proposed delineation process. 2.2. Data-driven soil moisture modeling with LSTM networks The second pivotal phase in designing a model-based closed-loop irrigation scheduler involves creating agro-hydrological models that are both computationally efficient and accurate in describing soil moisture dynamics within each irrigation management zone obtained in Section 2.1. This section introduces an approach for identifying concise data-driven agro-hydrological models using LSTM networks. LSTM networks are a type of recurrent neural network (RNN) that can effectively capture long term dependencies. This special type of RNN is selected for its effectiveness in representing complex causal systems, such as an agro-hydrological system. It is noteworthy that leveraging long-term, in situ soil water measurements and weather data from agricultural fields is one of the most effective approaches for accurately identifying data-driven agro-hydrological models. However, in situations where long-term data is not readily available, utilizing open-loop simulated data from properly calibrated mechanistic models serves as a valuable alternative for developing accurate data-driven models. In this study, the latter approach, depicted in Fig. 2, is employed to identify data-driven agro-hydrological models for the delineated management zones. The management zone delineation approach presented in Section 2.1 relies on soil hydraulic parameters estimated from real-time soil moisture measurements obtained from the field under study. Consequently, the soil hydraulic parameters corresponding to the centroid of each management zone (or cluster) are expected to offer a reliable representation of the soil properties within each respective zone. By calibrating a mechanistic agro-hydrological model with these centroidal soil hydraulic parameters, the mechanistic model is anticipated to accurately describe the soil moisture dynamics in each management zone. Subsequently, open-loop simulated data from this calibrated model can be utilized to develop an accurate data-driven agro-hydrological model for the respective management zone. Download : Download high-res image (425KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 2. LSTM network development. This section begins with a description of the mechanistic agro-hydrological model, specifically the Richards equation, that is employed in this study. It concludes with a discussion on how LSTM networks can be leveraged to identify a compact data-driven agro-hydrological model capable of predicting root zone soil moisture content in each management zone while accounting for the time-varying nature of crop rooting depth, using open-loop simulated data from the calibrated Richards equation. 2.2.1. Richards equation The Richards equation is a mechanistic agro-hydrological model that can be used to model the transport of water in soil. In this study, the 1D version (in the axial direction) of the Richards equation, calibrated with the centroidal soil hydraulic parameters in each management zone, is employed to accurately describe the water transport within each zone. This choice is justified by considering that elevation information was factored into the management zone delineation process, and as a result, the elevation profile within a specific management zone is expected to remain relatively uniform. The 1D version of the Richards equation is expressed as: (1) In Eq. (1), is the capillary pressure head, which describes the status of water in soil, represents time, is the spatial coordinate, is the unsaturated hydraulic water conductivity, is the capillary capacity. Note that and are parameterized functions that are relevant for solving Eq. (1). is a dimensionless stress water factor, is the root water uptake model which is a function of the crop coefficient , the reference evapotranspiration , and the rooting depth . In order to solve the 1D Richards equation numerically, the following boundary conditions are typically imposed: (2) (3) where , , and in Eqs. (2), (3) represent the depth of the soil column, the irrigation rate and the evaporation rate, respectively. The method of lines numerical approach proposed in Agyeman, Sahoo et al. (2023) is employed to solve Eq. (1). Additionally, the precise mathematical expressions for , and can be found in Agyeman et al. (2021). Interested readers may refer to the aforementioned references for a detailed explanation of the numerical approach. The volumetric water content is chosen as the output . Eq. (6) is thus a general representation of Eq. Training data generation The training dataset is generated by solving Eqs. (5), (6) for randomly generated inputs and initial states , with some level of noise included in the simulations to account for model uncertainty and to enhance the generalization ability and robustness of the LSTM network. Model uncertainty is treated as additive in nature. During open-loop simulations of the Richards equation, this uncertainty is modeled through realizations drawn from a Gaussian distribution with zero mean. The variance of this distribution is determined based on simulation experiments, ensuring a realistic representation of uncertainty. The use of randomly generated inputs and initial states is suggested to ensure that the dataset encompasses the dynamics of soil moisture under various conditions. For irrigation scheduling purposes, it is important to focus on the soil moisture dynamics in the entire root zone of a particular management zone. Thus, once the open-loop simulations are completed, the computation of root zone soil water content at each time step in the dataset becomes necessary. In this study, this is achieved by utilizing the volumetric soil moisture content vector obtained at each time step in the dataset. To determine the root zone soil moisture content, a weighted sum is applied to the elements in the volumetric soil moisture content vector. The weights are assigned as follows: 40% to the average volumetric moisture content value in the upper quarter of the rooting depth , 30% to the average value in the second quarter, 20% to the average value in the third quarter, and 10% to the average value in the last quarter. This weighting effectively captures the relative importance of moisture at different depths within the crop rooting depth, ensuring an effective representation of root zone soil moisture dynamics for irrigation scheduling purposes. 2.2.3. Model design The LSTM network is trained to make daily predictions of the root zone volumetric moisture content. Its primary objective is to forecast the root zone volumetric water content one day ahead ( ), denoted as . To achieve this, the network utilizes both current ( ) and past inputs ( , , …, ), where represents the time lag (in days) or sequence length used for model development. The specific inputs to the network include the root zone volumetric water content , precipitation (i.e. the sum of rain and irrigation rate) , crop coefficient , reference evapotranspiration , and the rooting depth . The incorporation of rooting depth as an input into the model is crucial because it enables the network to account for the time-varying nature of the rooting depth. Mathematically, the identified LSTM model can be expressed as: (7) where ≔ and . In Eq. (7), is a compact representation of the weights and biases of the LSTM network . 2.2.4. Model evaluation A comparative study is conducted to assess the predictive performance of the trained LSTM networks. In this comparative study, a specific initial state is chosen, and predetermined trajectories are defined for the precipitation, crop coefficient, and reference evapotranspiration inputs over a specified period. Subsequently, both the identified LSTM network and its corresponding calibrated 1D Richards equation are simulated using the selected initial state and predefined input trajectories. The predictions generated by the data-driven model are then compared against the computed root zone soil moisture content obtained from the calibrated Richards equation. The assessment of prediction accuracy utilizes the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), as expressed by Eq. (B.1) in Appendix B.3. 2.3. Mixed-integer MPC with zone control for irrigation scheduling The irrigation scheduling problem, originally proposed in Agyeman, Sahoo et al. (2023), is modeled as a variant of the warehouse location problem, where the irrigation implementing equipment plays the role of a warehouse, and the decision to operate the equipment is treated as the decision to operate a warehouse. In this context, the fixed cost of operating the equipment is analogously considered as the fixed cost of opening a warehouse, while the variable cost of supplying water to the agricultural field is equated to the variable cost of operating a warehouse. The objective function is to minimize the total cost (fixed and variable) of operating the irrigation equipment over a planning horizon, subject to constraints that ensure that the demand for water in each management zone is met, and that the total supply of water does not exceed the capacity of the irrigation equipment. To modify the formulation to maintain the root zone soil moisture within a target zone, a penalty for violating the target zone is added to the objective function, and the constraints are updated to ensure that the root zone soil moisture is maintained within the target zone. Furthermore, the dynamics of root zone soil moisture must be considered during the planning horizon, as the root zone soil moisture level changes over the planning horizon. This modified formulation results in a mixed-integer MPC problem with zone objectives (zone control), where the identified data-driven agro-hydrological model for each management zone is employed as the dynamic model in the formulation. Additionally, a soft constraint approach is employed to realize the objective of maintaining the root zone soil moisture in the target zone where slack variables are introduced in the formulation to relax the bounds of the target zone. By solving the mixed-integer MPC with zone objectives problem, the optimal schedules (daily irrigation decision and daily irrigation rate) for operating the irrigation equipment can be determined that minimize the total cost of operation while maintaining the root zone soil moisture within the target zone throughout the planning horizon. To facilitate a better understanding of the proposed scheduler formulation for fields comprising multiple management zones, the formulation is initially applied to a field with a single management zone. For day within a planning horizon of days, the scheduler is formulated for a single management zone as follows: (8a) (8b) (8c) (8d) (8e) (8f) (8g) where , ≔ , ≔ , ≔ , ≔ , and ≔ where . and ((8a), (8g)) are nonnegative slack variables that are introduced to relax the bounds of the target zone in (8d). In this work, and (also known as the threshold volumetric moisture content ) are calculated as follows: (9) (10) where is the volumetric moisture content at field capacity, represents the volumetric water content at the wilting point, and MAD refers to the management allowable depletion, which indicates the fraction of the total available water that is permitted to be depleted. The per-unit costs associated with the violation of the lower and upper bounds of the target zone are represented with and , respectively. and represent the per-unit cost of the applied irrigation amount and the fixed cost associated with operating the irrigation implementing equipment, respectively. The binary decision variable encodes the daily irrigation decision. The cost function (8a) incorporates the objectives of maintaining the root zone volumetric moisture content in a target zone in order to ensure optimal water uptake in crops by minimizing the violation of the target zone , minimizing the irrigation cost , and minimizing the irrigation amount . Constraint (8b) corresponds to the LSTM model of the root zone volumetric moisture content, and in this constraint represents the weights and bias terms associated with the identified LSTM model. In this work, the initial state is represented with Constraint (8c). Its value is assumed to be known during the evaluation of the scheduler. In particular, it is chosen to be the estimated state obtained after the state and parameter estimation step outlined in Section 2.1 has converged. Constraint (8e) refers to the maximum amount of water that can be supplied during an irrigation event on day . When the irrigation decision on day is “a no decision” ( ), Constraint (8e) requires that the irrigation rate must be set to 0. Conversely, when the irrigation decision on a particular day is “a yes decision” ( ), Constraint (8e) specifies that the prescribed irrigation rate must not exceed its upper bound ( ) and must be at least as large as its lower bound ( ). Enhancing the computational efficiency of : Decentralized hybrid actor-critic agents and limiting management zone While numerical optimization methods, such as the branch and bound technique, can be used to solve , they may encounter computational challenges, especially when dealing with agricultural fields comprising a large number of irrigation management zones. To overcome these computational issues, this study proposes an alternative approach employing decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and the concept of a limiting irrigation management zone to enhance the computational efficiency of . This section begins with a detailed description of how the hybrid actor–critic agent is employed to train an agent for a specific management zone of the field. It concludes with a discussion of how the decentralized agents and the concept of a limiting management zone are combined to enhance the computational efficiency of the scheduler. 2.4.1. Agent design and training This study proposes the training of a RL agent for each of the management zones present in the agricultural field. Each agent is trained to determine the daily irrigation decision (discrete action) and the daily irrigation rate (continuous action) that optimize root water uptake while minimizing irrigation costs and total water consumption in a management zone. The hybrid actor–critic approach, as originally introduced in Fan et al. (2019), is adopted for the training of each agent due to its demonstrated effectiveness in handling both discrete and continuous action spaces. This hybrid actor–critic architecture comprises two parallel actor networks, where one actor learns the discrete action (daily irrigation decision in this work) and the other learns the continuous action (daily irrigation rate in this work). The parallel actors share a single critic network, which serves as an estimate of the state-value function. The RL framework of the agent is modeled as a fully observable Markov Decision Process (MDP), comprising several elements such as observations, actions, rewards, and transition/dynamics functions. This section begins with a detailed description of the environment with which the hybrid actor–critic agent interacts during its training stage. Additionally, the design of the observations which serve as inputs to the agent’s policy is outlined. Subsequently, the reward design employed in agent training is discussed, followed by a discussion of the agent’s training. Environment design. In the training process of a hybrid actor–critic agent, the environmental dynamics are represented by a 1D Richards equation calibrated with the centroidal hydraulic parameters of the relevant management zone. The delineation of management zones is based on soil hydraulic parameters estimated from real-time observations in the agricultural field. Utilizing a 1D Richards equation calibrated with the centroidal hydraulic parameters of each management zone ensures an accurate description of the soil moisture dynamics within the considered management zone. The transition dynamics for this calibrated 1D Richards equation are detailed in Eqs. (5), (6). Observation design. The policy of the hybrid actor–critic agent receives as input the output vector , denoting the volumetric moisture contents obtained from Eq. (6), alongside the reference evapotranspiration, crop coefficient, and rooting depth on day . These inputs, collectively represented as , provide essential information to the agent’s policy, aiding in the accurate determination of daily irrigation schedules. The output vector, constituting the first element of the observation vector, is considered a reliable representation of the volumetric soil distribution in the management zone under consideration. This reliability arises from its initialization with converged volumetric moisture content estimates obtained from the offline simultaneous state and parameter estimation in Stage 2 of the management zone delineation process. Additionally, reference evapotranspiration and crop coefficient can be readily obtained from weather predictions and empirical relations, respectively. The rooting depth can also be determined based on the crop’s growth stage. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the observation provided to the policy of the proposed agent is known, justifying the adoption of the fully observable MDP framework during the training of the agents. Reward design. The reward function employed during the training of the agents is expressed as: (12) (13) In Eqs. (12), (13), , , , , , and have the same definitions as in the scheduler formulation of . represents the root zone soil moisture on day , which is calculated using the weighted average approach outlined in Section 2.2.2. The agent incurs a penalty of when its actions result in the root zone soil moisture content falling below the lower threshold . Similarly, the agent is penalized with if its actions cause the root zone soil moisture content to exceed the upper threshold . When the agent successfully maintains the root zone soil moisture within the desired range, it receives a reward of 0. A penalty of is incurred when the agent decides to perform irrigation (indicated by a “yes” decision) and a penalty of is incurred for a non-zero irrigation rate. Agent training. The Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm (Schulman, Wolski, Dhariwal, Radford, & Klimov, 2017) is applied for policy optimization in the parallel actors. During the training stage of the agent, to generate a stochastic policy for the irrigation decision, the discrete actor network of the hybrid PPO outputs two values for the 2 discrete actions (0,1). Additionally, the discrete action is sampled from the softmax distribution. The continuous actor network of the hybrid PPO generates the stochastic policy for the daily irrigation rate by outputting the mean and variance for the daily irrigation rate action. For a more detailed understanding of the PPO algorithm and the hybrid PPO approach, interested readers may refer to Fan et al. (2019) and Schulman et al. (2017), respectively.
