Hybrid actor–critic architecture, and agent–environment interaction. 2.4.2. A multi-agent MPC paradigm: Limiting management zone and evaluation of After training the hybrid PPO agents, each agent is utilized to determine the irrigation decisions and rates for its corresponding management zone. As these agents are intended to contribute to the solution of formulation , each agent undergoes evaluation across the planning horizon used in . The evaluation of each agent over the horizon involves providing the necessary inputs, such as the initial volumetric moisture content for a specific day and predicted/forecasted uncontrolled inputs (reference evapotranspiration, crop coefficient, and rooting depths) over the prediction horizon, to the policy of the trained agent. In response, the trained agent yields optimal or near-optimal irrigation decisions and rates for the planning horizon by interacting with the calibrated 1D Richards equation of the relevant management zone. The interaction between a hybrid agent and its environment is illustrated in Fig. 4. In this figure, the predicted uncontrolled inputs over are represented as , with the initial volumetric moisture content denoted as . Furthermore, and in Fig. 4 correspond to the daily irrigation decision and daily irrigation depth prescribed by the agent. This evaluation yields an irrigation decision sequence and an irrigation depth sequence, designated as and , respectively. The evaluation process is repeated for all agents to generate irrigation decision sequences and irrigation depth sequences. The decentralized approach employed during the training of the hybrid agents results in a situation where the irrigation decision sequences obtained for all the management zones are nonuniform. However, this nonuniformity in irrigation decision sequences is inconsistent with the requirements of formulation , which demands a uniform irrigation decision sequence across the management zones. The concept of a limiting management zone is employed to address the nonuniformity arising from the decentralized nature of agent training. The limiting irrigation management zone is defined as the th management zone that exhibits the earliest non-zero irrigation decision within the planning horizon. The irrigation decision sequence of the limiting management zone is chosen as a binding irrigation decision sequence for all the management zones. By adopting the irrigation decision sequence from the limiting management zone as the binding sequence, the scheduler can ensure timely irrigation across all management zones. An illustrative example can help clarify the concepts of the limiting irrigation management zone and binding irrigation sequence. Consider a field divided into three management zones: , , and . Each zone has its own hybrid PPO agent with a designated policy: , , and . On a given day, denoted as , the observations within each management zone are represented as , , and . It is assumed that the agents are evaluated for a planning horizon of seven days. After evaluating the agents, the following irrigation sequences ( ) were obtained: , , and . Based on the irrigation sequences obtained, it is evident that exhibits the earliest non-zero irrigation decision among all the management zones. Consequently, is identified as the limiting irrigation management zone. By designating as the limiting management zone, it is established that the irrigation decisions made within serve as the reference for irrigation scheduling in the other zones. The binding sequence of , , is enforced in and . Once the binding irrigation decision sequence is determined, it is enforced in . Given that the binary variables over the planning horizon (binding irrigation decision sequence) in have already been calculated, the nonlinear programming version of can be solved to determine the irrigation rates over the planning horizon in the management zones. This approach transforms from a Mixed-Integer Nonlinear Program (MINLP) to a Nonlinear Programming (NLP) problem, significantly enhancing the computational efficiency of . The solution of the NLP version of can be avoided altogether. Instead, copies of the NLP version of corresponding to the management zones can be solved in parallel, after the binding irrigation decision sequence has been enforced in each formulation. It is evident from that the irrigation decision sequence is responsible for the coupling among the management zones in . Additionally, formulation merely replicates formulation in the management zones. Thus, after the irrigation decision sequence in has been determined using the binding irrigation decision sequence approach, the NLP version of can be solved in each of the management zones in parallel. This parallel execution can take advantage of the multicore architecture of modern CPUs, leading to substantial reductions in computation time and significantly improving the overall computational efficiency of the scheduler. Fig. 5 illustrates the comprehensive approach incorporating hybrid PPO agents, the limiting management zone, and the copies of . The irrigation rates determined by the hybrid PPO agent in the limiting management zone can be directly implemented as they align with the binding irrigation decision sequence across the planning horizon. However, for the remaining management zones, the irrigation rates obtained from the hybrid PPO agents can only serve as a reliable initial guess, as they do not precisely match the binding sequence. In these management zones, the NLP versions of must necessarily be solved to obtain the optimal irrigation rates. Notably, an irrigation rate sequence is considered to align with an irrigation decision sequence when a non-zero irrigation rate in the sequence corresponds to a decision of an irrigation decision of 1, and a zero irrigation rate in the sequence corresponds to an irrigation decision of 0. This consistency must be maintained for all days within the planning horizon. Remark 2 The integration of decisions from hybrid actor–critic agents into the MPC layer demonstrates a cooperation between multi-agent systems and MPC, leading to what can be referred to as a multi-agent MPC paradigm. This approach shares some similarities with distributed MPC and coalitional MPC methods, where decisions are made locally by individual agents/control units based on localized information to achieve a global objective. However, there are notable differences between the proposed approach and these control methods. Hybrid actor–critic agents, which eventually aid in determining irrigation decisions, are trained in a fully decentralized manner, without inter-agent communication during their training phase. This training also ignores the coupling constraint of the irrigation scheduling problem that necessitates uniform daily irrigation decisions across all management zones/agents. To manage this constraint, the proposed approach adopts a heuristic method based on a limiting management zone to reconcile the daily irrigation decisions when the agents are executed. This decentralized training contrasts with distributed or coalitional methods that generally involve agent communication to enhance performance. Moreover, the heuristic method for addressing coupling constraints deviates from consensus algorithms and coordination schemes typically used in distributed training techniques to handle coupling constraints. Furthermore, the proposed approach relies on the reconciled irrigation decisions to solve multiple MPCs in parallel so as to determine the optimal irrigation rates for each management zone. This process is characterized as fully decentralized MPC since it does not involve communication between the local MPCs of different management zones, differing from distributed or coalitional MPC approaches that would involve inter-local MPC communication. Importantly, the adoption of a fully decentralized MPC approach in determining the irrigation rates for different management zones assumes a weak coupling between these zones. While this approach is suitable for large-scale fields, such as the field considered in the work, it is inappropriate for smaller, spatially variable fields where a stronger coupling exists between management zones. In such scenarios, a distributed MPC approach, which involves communication between local MPCs to ensure the system’s closed-loop stability, would be more suitable. The binding irrigation decision sequence is subsequently utilized to solve instances of the formulation , determining the irrigation depths for the management zones. 2.5. Comparative evaluation of proposed and triggered irrigation scheduling methods Evaluating the benefits of the proposed irrigation scheduling approach over the entire crop growing season is essential for understanding its effectiveness. To achieve this, the study employs the widely employed triggered irrigation scheduling approach as a benchmark. A comparison is made between the proposed scheduler and the triggered approach in terms of Irrigation Water Use Efficiency (IWUE), also known as water productivity and total irrigation prescribed. Despite the fundamental differences, comparing the two approaches in terms of IWUE and total prescribed irrigation is considered essential for several reasons. Firstly, the triggered approach serves as a widely adopted and practical benchmark, allowing for the evaluation of potential improvements offered by the more advanced MPC-based scheduling. Furthermore, the comparison offers insights into the water conservation capabilities of each approach, providing valuable considerations for the adoption of sustainable agriculture practices in response to the challenges of global water scarcity. This section first provides a description of the triggered irrigation scheduling approach. It then proceeds to explain the calculation of the irrigation water use efficiency. 2.5.1. Triggered irrigation scheduling This scheduling approach aims to maintain the root zone soil moisture within the lower and upper bounds of a target zone. In this approach, an irrigation event is triggered on a specific day, denoted as , when the daily root zone moisture content, represented by , falls below the lower bound of the target zone, denoted as . When such a situation occurs, the irrigation rate for that day, denoted as , is calculated using the following formula (Gu et al., 2021): (14) In Eq. (14), represents the rooting depth, while corresponds to the upper bound of the target zone. indicates the cumulative precipitation that occurs from day to . The interested reader may refer to Gu et al. (2020) and the references therein for a thorough discussion of this scheduling approach. 2.5.2. Irrigation water use efficiency In this work, the Irrigation Water Use Efficiency (IWUE) in kg/m is calculated as follows (15) where is the predicted yield in (kg/m2) and IRR is the total prescribed irrigation depth applied in meters ( ). The detailed calculation of can be found in Appendix A. 2.6. Study area A large-scale agricultural field is employed to assess the benefits of the proposed scheduling approach. The field in question is a Research Farm operated by Lethbridge College and it spans an area of 26.4 hectares. The field is located in Lethbridge, southern Alberta, with geographic coordinates approximately at latitude 49.72°N and longitude 112.80°W. A layout of the investigated field is shown in Fig. 6(a). The average elevation of the area is 888 m. Regarding the soil composition, the predominant texture in the field is clayey loam, with occasional presence of sand lenses. To facilitate effective irrigation management, a five-span center pivot system has been installed in the field. This mechanized irrigation system follows a circular pattern around a central pivot and the pivot has a total length of 294 m. Furthermore, the center pivot system incorporates a commercial variable rate irrigation system, enabling variable irrigation application rates. To monitor soil moisture levels of the field during the rotation cycle of the pivot, microwave remote sensors have been installed on the five spans of the pivot. The field exhibits varying elevations, ranging from 886 m at the lowest point to 890 m at the highest point. An interpolated field elevation map, depicted in Fig. 6(b), visually represents this elevation distribution. To prepare for the implementation of the proposed management zone delineation approach and the evaluation of proposed irrigation scheduler, soil moisture observations were collected using microwave remote sensors installed on the center pivot of the field. These observations were utilized to estimate both the soil water content and soil hydraulic parameters across the entire field. The estimation process covered the period from May 16, 2022, to August 31, 2022. In this section, two of the estimated parameters are presented: the saturated hydraulic conductivity ( ) and the curve fitting parameter ( ), to provide a brief overview of the estimation results. The spatial maps of these two estimated hydraulic parameters are depicted in Fig. 7. Download : Download high-res image (725KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 6. Description of the study area. Download : Download high-res image (746KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 7. Spatial maps of some estimated hydraulic parameters. 2.6.1. Management zone delineation of the study area In this section, the proposed three-stage management zone delineation process is applied to the study area, and the results of the delineation are presented in Fig. 8. During the first stage of delineation, the field under study was divided into 4 management zones, labeled as Quadrants 1, 2, 3, and 4 in Fig. 8. This initial division is based on the fact that 4 different crop types are commonly planted in the respective quadrants of the study area. Consequently, the initial delineation of the field according to crop types results in these 4 management zones. After the initial delineation, the second stage of the process involved refining the management zones using the elevation and the estimated soil hydraulic parameters attributes within Quadrants 1, 2, 3, and 4. As shown in Fig. 8, this resulted in 5 irregularly shaped management zones in Quadrant 1, 4 irregularly shaped management zones in Quadrant 2, and 3 irregularly shaped management zones in Quadrants 3 and 4. Finally, in the third stage of the delineation process, the irregularly shaped management zones obtained in the second stage were mapped to the resolution of the field’s center pivot. Specifically, the field’s center pivot has a resolution of 12 zones and 45 zones in the radial and azimuthal directions, respectively. For simplicity and comprehensive analysis, the results for the third quadrant of the field are isolated and discussed in detail. Fig. 9(a) depicts the management zone map obtained after the second stage of the management zone delineation process. It is evident that the clustering approach resulted in three distinct, irregularly shaped management zones. Fig. 9(b) displays the spatial distribution of the three irrigation management zones, which were mapped to align with the resolution of the field’s center pivot. Based on the centroidal hydraulic parameters and the centroidal elevation, Management Zone 1 (MZ ) was found to have an average soil hydraulic parameter set corresponding to loamy soil, with an associated elevation of 889 m. Similarly, Management Zone 2 (MZ ) exhibited an average soil hydraulic parameter set of loamy soil, but with an average elevation of 888 m. In Management Zone 3 (MZ ), the average soil type was identified as sandy clay loam, and the average elevation measured 888.5 m. Download : Download high-res image (575KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 8. A diagrammatic representation of the results of the three-stage irrigation management zone delineation approach applied to the study area. Download : Download high-res image (814KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 9. Irrigation management zones and corresponding pivot resolution representation of the zones. Subsequently, the remaining steps of the proposed scheduling approach are specifically implemented in Quadrant 3 of the study area, for the sake of simplicity. This adopted approach also allows for a thorough examination of the outcomes obtained through the proposed scheduling approach. It should be noted that applying the same steps to the remaining quadrants can be done straightforwardly, without any loss of generality. 2.7. Simulation settings In this section, specific details regarding the simulation settings and parameters used during the application of the remaining steps of the scheduling approach to Quadrant 3 of the study area are provided. The section begins by presenting the settings and parameters employed during the development of the 3 LSTM networks for soil moisture content modeling in the 3 management zones of Quadrant 3. It then proceeds to describe the settings and parameters used during the training of distinct hybrid PPO agents for the 3 management zones of Quadrant 3. Finally, the settings, parameters, and weather data employed during the evaluation of the proposed scheduler on a large-scale agricultural field are presented. It is noteworthy that the performance of the scheduler is assessed over two growing seasons. Additionally, for each growing season, evaluations are conducted for two different Mean Absolute Difference (MAD) values: specifically, 40% and 65%. 2.7.1. LSTM network training Prior to generating the open-loop data for LSTM network development, the dynamics of soil moisture in each of the 3 management zones of Quadrant 3 was modeled using the 1D Richards equation. These Richards equations were calibrated with the centroidal hydraulic parameters specific to each irrigation management zone. Subsequently, extensive open-loop simulations of these calibrated Richards equations were conducted, incorporating randomly generated inputs (i.e. reference evapotranspiration, crop coefficient, and irrigation rate inputs) and initial states (capillary pressure head and volumetric soil moisture content). The simulation settings used during these open-loop simulations of the Richards equation are detailed in Table B.6 of Appendix B.1. To ensure accurate irrigation scheduling for the crop type present in Quadrant 3, which in this case was spring soft wheat, the LSTM training stage incorporated two different rooting depths: 0.5 m and 1.00 m. The reference evapotranspiration and crop coefficient were randomly generated within the ranges of 0.1 mm/day to 8.99 mm/day and 0.4 to 1.02, respectively, for all three management zones. The irrigation rate was randomly generated between 4.0 mm/day and 52.0 mm/day for MZ , 4.3 mm/day and 59.6 mm/day for MZ , and 5.0 mm/day and 62.3 mm/day for MZ . It is important to note that the selection of input ranges for the open-loop simulations of the calibrated 1D Richards equation was informed by historical weather data and local irrigation management practices. After computing the root zone soil moisture content at each time step using the methodology outlined in Section 2.2.2, the LSTM models were trained using the Keras Library in Python. The model architecture and hyperparameters employed during the training process are provided in Table B.7 of Appendix B.2, and it is worth mentioning that these values were determined through experimentation. Consequently, it is plausible that more optimal results could be achieved through a systematic tuning of the hyperparameter values. 2.7.2. Hybrid PPO agent training A summary of the final parameter values for the formulations and used in training 3 distinct hybrid PPO agents for the three management zones in Quadrant 3 is provided in Table D.9 of Appendix D. It is important to note that the per unit costs in these formulations were considered as tuning parameters in this study. Tuning these costs involved exploring multiple scenarios by adjusting the per unit costs in and . Through an iterative process, the performance of the agents was evaluated under different cost configurations, leading to the determination of the most suitable values for achieving the desired irrigation management objectives. The values of the volumetric moisture content at field capacity and wilting point for the various soil types present in the 3 management zones in Quadrant 3 were obtained from Ref. Huffman, Fangmeier, Elliot, and Workman (2012). To represent the policies of the actor networks for the discrete (daily irrigation decision) and continuous (daily irrigation rate) actions in each hybrid PPO agent, a fully connected multilayer perceptron with two hidden layers and a hyperbolic tangent (tanh) activation function was employed. The hyperparameters utilized during the training of the agents, as well as other settings specific to the PPO algorithm, are summarized in Table C.8 of Appendix C. Additionally since the evaluation of the scheduler under a particular growing season is done for MAD values of 40% and 65%, 3 distinct hybrid PPO agents are trained for an MAD of 40%, and another set of 3 hybrid PPO agents are trained for an MAD of 65%. The training of the hybrid PPO agents was conducted using the Tensorforce library (Schaarschmidt et al., 2018) in Python. 2.7.3. Evaluation setup and parameters for proposed scheduler As has already been mentioned, the proposed scheduler is evaluated over two growing seasons: the 2015 and 2022 seasons, for MAD values of 40% and 65%. Fig. E.16 of Appendix E.1 presents the relevant weather data utilized in this study, specifically from the selected growing seasons. It is important to note that a MAD value of 40% is commonly used for irrigation management on the Research farm, and in irrigation management, this value can be considered to be conservative. Therefore, the scheduler was further assessed using a less conservative MAD value of 65% to evaluate its ability to ensure optimal plant growth when allowing for more water depletion in the root zone. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the 2015 season had lower total rainfall of 141.7 mm compared to the 2022 season which recorded a total value of 230.9 mm. These seasons were chosen to assess the performance of the scheduler in relatively dry and wet conditions. Soft spring wheat was cultivated in the investigated quadrant during the 2022 season, and this crop was also considered for the 2015 growing season. To determine the initial volumetric moisture content (and for that matter the initial capillary pressure head) for each management zone, the converged volumetric soil moisture estimates obtained from the estimation procedure outlined in Section 2.1 were first mapped to the management zone map of Quadrant 3. For each management zone, the volumetric soil moisture estimates corresponding to the driest plot were selected as the basis for initializing the scheduler. It is important to note, however, that the accuracy of these volumetric moisture estimates are expected to decline over time, and soil moisture content observations from the management zones in the field under study should be used to correct these estimates using various data assimilation techniques. The incorporation of data assimilation techniques in model-based irrigation schedulers is outside the scope of this work, and the interested reader may explore references such as Agyeman et al. (2021) and Bo and Liu (2020) that delve into soil moisture estimation in agro-hydrological systems. The scheduler is implemented in a receding horizon manner, where the calibrated 1D Richards equations of the three management zones serve as the representation of the real field. In the evaluation phase, a prediction horizon of 14 days is utilized. It is noteworthy that a control horizon of 14 days was also employed during the evaluation stage. Simulation experiments revealed that a 14-day prediction horizon effectively captures the essential dynamics of the agro-hydrological system examined in this study. This period also enables the scheduler to utilize the most accurate weather forecasts available. Additionally, the selected timeframe was found to be sufficiently long to ensure that the receding horizon implementation of the scheduler is stabilizing. Moreover, a 14-day prediction horizon was found to ensure computational efficiency of the scheduling process by facilitating a timely optimization process. While the true weather information, such as rainfall, reference evapotranspiration, and average temperature, is known during the simulations, uncertainty is incorporated into the weather forecasts used over the prediction horizon. This was done to assess the robustness of the scheduler to uncertainties in weather forecasts. The uncertainty in the weather forecast is modeled as a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a specified standard deviation. As the prediction horizon extends further into the future, the standard deviation values are gradually increased to reflect the increasing uncertainty associated with longer-term weather predictions. Table D.9 of Appendix D provides the relevant parameters of formulation used in evaluating the scheduler. The evaluation period for each growing season spanned from 5th May to 4th September, encompassing a total of 123 evaluations. In each evaluation, the three hybrid PPO agents were initially assessed using relevant observations from all three management zones to obtain irrigation decision sequences for the prediction horizon. Subsequently, the binding irrigation sequence was determined, and three copies of formulation (y) were simultaneously evaluated to optimize the irrigation rates for each management zone using the interior point optimization solver (Wächter & Biegler, 2006). In accordance with the receding horizon implementation of the scheduler, the first element of the optimal irrigation rates for all the three management zones were then applied to the calibrated 1D Richards equations. The soil water content resulting from the implemented irrigation rate in each management zone was then used to initialize the subsequent evaluation of the scheduler. Throughout the evaluation process, a rooting depth of 0.5 m was considered from 5th May to 15th July. From the 16th of July to the end of the growing season, a rooting depth of 1.0 m was used to determine the irrigation schedules. It is worth noting that this practice is consistent with irrigation management of the soft spring wheat crop. Both the triggered approach and the proposed approach were utilized to generate irrigation schedules for the selected growing seasons and specific MAD values. For the evaluation of the predicted yield under both scheduling schemes, the parameters and in Eq. (A.1) were set to 0.88 kg m−2 and 1.15, respectively. These values were obtained from Ref. Bennett and Harms (2011) and represent calibrated values specific to the study area. 3. Results and discussion In this section, the results obtained after the application of the proposed irrigation scheduler to Quadrant 3 of the field are presented and discussed in detail. This section begins with a presentation and discussion of the results obtained from the validation experiment conducted on the identified LSTM networks for soil moisture dynamics modeling in Quadrant 3. Next, the results of the hybrid PPO agents are presented, after which a discussion of these results is presented. Finally, the irrigation schedules, and the corresponding root zone soil moisture content obtained under the proposed and triggered irrigation scheduling schemes, over the two growing seasons, are presented and discussed in detail. 3.1. Validation of the trained LSTM networks The results of the validation experiment, which was conducted over a 30 day period, is depicted in Fig. 10. From this figure, the soil moisture predictions can be deemed accurate, since there is a good agreement between the root zone soil moisture predictions and the actual root zone soil moisture content derived from the calibrated 1D Richards equation. This accuracy is reinforced by the low RMSE values shown in Table 1, which serve to support the good predictive capacity of the identified LSTM models for root zone soil moisture content across all three management zones at depths of 0.50 m and 1.00 m. The results obtained from the validation experiment further highlight the accuracy of the identified LSTM networks in performing multi-step-ahead predictions. In this experiment, the LSTM models, originally trained to predict a single day ahead, were employed in a recursive manner across the 30-day period. This recursive strategy involved using the output at a specific time step as an input in the subsequent time step. This recursive use of the identified LSTM networks holds significance within model predictive control frameworks, such as the mixed-integer MPC with zone control formulation that is adopted for irrigation scheduling in this work. The obtained results in this section provide evidence that the proposed LSTM network root zone soil moisture modeling in the delineated management zones is both robust and accurate. These findings align with several other studies that have also utilized LSTM models to describe soil moisture dynamics in agro-hydrological systems (Adeyemi et al., 2018, Agyeman, Sahoo et al., 2023). Furthermore, these findings imply that a neural networks’ capacity for universal approximation can be harnessed to directly characterize root zone soil moisture content. This approach is anticipated to enhance the computational efficiency when employed in schedulers that require the solution of a numerical optimization problem. This new approach stands in contrast to earlier works (Gu et al., 2021), where distinct neural network models were trained to predict the soil moisture content at different depths within the soil profile, after which a weighted approach was employed to obtain the root zone soil moisture content from the soil moisture predictions. The results of the validation experiment further confirms the hypothesis that by including the rooting depth as one of the inputs to the LSTM network, the time varying nature of the rooting depth and its effect on the root zone soil moisture can be effective modeled. Table 1. Predictive performance of the trained LSTM models over a period of 30 days. Predictive performance of the identified LSTM models for the considered rooting depths. 3.2. Performance of the hybrid PPO agents To provide a concise summary, the trajectories of the rewards obtained during the training stage for the MAD of 40% are presented. Fig. 11 demonstrates the average episodic rewards obtained after running each agent 10 times, showing an upward trend that indicates an improvement in agent performance over successive training iterations. Additionally, the hybrid PPO agents exhibit convergence to stable and optimal policies, as evidenced by the rewards reaching a plateau during the training stage. Overall, the trained hybrid PPO agents can effectively provide optimal irrigation decisions tailored to their respective management zones. This finding aligns with earlier studies (Fan et al., 2019, Xu and Lin, 2023) that have demonstrated the ability of the hybrid actor–critic approach in achieving stable learning when employed in mixed-integer optimal control problems. The proposed hybrid actor–critic paradigm adds to the range of approximation methods aimed at simplifying mixed-integer optimal control problems. Notable alternatives include the sigmoid approximation (de Oliveira, Da Silva, Pereira, & Carneiro, 2005) and the time-step grouping (Richards & How, 2005) approach. The proposed approach offers advantages over the sigmoid approach used in the mixed-integer MPC for irrigation scheduling proposed in Agyeman, Sahoo et al. (2023) and Agyeman, Nouri et al. (2023). Specifically, the RL approach, by directly learning an optimal/near-optimal policy for the binary variable, eliminates the approximation errors associated with the sigmoid function. Additionally, the RL approach addresses interpretability issues encountered in the sigmoid approach. Moreover, compared to the complexity introduced by time step grouping method, the hybrid actor–critic paradigm, simplifies the process by directly learning optimal policies for binary variables at each time step, eliminating the need for manual decisions on strategies to group binary variables across timesteps. Despite these benefits, it is essential to note that the RL training process is time-consuming due to its complexity. Future research should explore methods to expedite agent training and determine the optimal number of training episodes for efficient agent learning. Download : Download high-res image (396KB) Download : Download full-size image Fig. 11. Trajectory of the average episodic rewards for the RL agents for each management zone. 3.3. Performance and utility of the proposed scheduler Figs. 14 and 15 depict the prescribed schedules and the dynamics of the root zone soil moisture during the 2022 growing season for MAD values of 40% and 65%, respectively. Similarly, Fig. 12, Fig. 13 show the prescribed schedules and the corresponding root zone soil moisture dynamics for the 2015 growing season with MAD values of 40% and 65%, respectively. Table 2, Table 3 present a summary of the total prescribed water and other relevant costs computed for the 2022 growing season, considering MAD values of 40% and 65% respectively. Similarly, Table 4, Table 5 provide the summary for the 2015 growing season with MAD values of 40% and 65% respectively. As mentioned previously, the 2015 growing season experienced lower total rainfall compared to the 2022 season. Consequently, both scheduling approaches resulted in higher total irrigation rates for the 2015 season compared to the 2022 season. Additionally, the results demonstrated that for an MAD of 40%, both scheduling approaches exhibited higher total irrigation rates compared to a less conservative MAD of 65%. Similarly, both approaches made more frequent irrigation decisions for an MAD of 40% compared to an MAD of 65%. This observation aligns with the definition of MAD, as a lower MAD implies a smaller allowable depletion of root zone soil moisture, necessitating more frequent irrigations and higher total irrigation application depths. Across all considered scenarios, the proposed approach consistently achieved lower total irrigation rates compared to the triggered approach. Specifically, for MAD 40%, the proposed approach saved approximately 6% and 7% of irrigation water in the 2015 and 2022 growing seasons, respectively. Similarly, for MAD 65%, the savings were about 14% and 23% for the same seasons. The obtained IWUE values indicated higher predicted crop yields under the proposed scheduling, evident from the higher IWUE values compared to the triggered approach. For MAD 40%, the proposed approach led to a 12% and 10% increase in IWUE in the 2022 and 2015 growing seasons, respectively. Likewise, for MAD 65%, there was a 35% and 20% increase in IWUE in the 2022 and 2015 growing seasons, respectively. The proposed approach exhibited more substantial water savings, particularly under the less conservative MAD value of 65%. Similarly, the enhancement in IWUE was more evident with the less conservative MAD value of 65%. The use of a conservative MAD value of 40% in irrigation scheduling aims to enhance the scheduler’s robustness against potential disturbances that could lead to crop stress. By setting the threshold further from the wilting point (critical point) with such conservative values, the likelihood of reaching critical soil moisture levels is reduced in the presence of disturbances. However, the simulation results suggest that less conservative MAD values can be employed under the proposed scheme, leading to reduced total irrigation rates while minimizing the risk of critical soil moisture levels. This indicates that the proposed approach offers flexibility in MAD selection, enabling a more efficient use of water resources while ensuring optimal crop development. In comparing the computational time between the proposed scheduler and the triggered approach, it became evident that the design and evaluation of the proposed approach required more time and computational effort. The estimation of soil hydraulic parameters for management zone delineation, along with the training of the decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and LSTM models, constitutes the most computationally intensive and time-consuming aspects of the proposed scheduler. Notably, the use of a high-dimensional field model in the estimation increases the computational effort needed for Jacobian calculations in the EKF step. Additionally, the iterative processes and hyperparameter adjustments associated with agent and LSTM model training contribute to extended training times. However, it is crucial to clarify that these computationally demanding steps are performed offline, thereby reducing the computational load during real-time operation. During online execution, involving the evaluation of hybrid agents, determining the limiting irrigation sequence, and solving the optimization problem for irrigation rates in all management zones of the field, the proposed approach demonstrated efficient performance. Parallel computing significantly influenced this efficiency during the optimization problem solution. While the current solution time is considered adequate for a scheduler sampling time of 1 day, applying the proposed approach to shorter sampling times may pose computational challenges, especially for fields with numerous management zones. Further studies are necessary to improve the computational efficiency of the proposed scheduler to ensure timely completion of the optimization problem within the sampling time. Exploring suboptimal solutions could be a potential avenue, though this may impact the water-saving benefits of the proposed approach. Table 2. The utilization of estimated hydraulic parameters, derived from the offline estimation in Stage 2 of the management zone delineation, as a basis for identifying the LSTM models, plays an important role in reducing parametric uncertainty and effectively addressing plant-model mismatch within the proposed scheduler. While this offline strategy serves as a good starting point for real-time implementation of the scheduler, it has limitations in adapting to real-time variations in field parameters. A more attractive approach to handle parameter variations involves performing online parameter estimation, utilizing real-time field observations for fine-tuning soil hydraulic parameters. However, it is essential to note that this online estimation approach may introduce additional computational demands to the online implementation of the scheduler. A valid alternative worth considering is the adoption of an offset-free MPC approach by incorporating a disturbance model. In this approach, managing plant-model mismatch is achieved by estimating disturbances through measurements, utilizing an augmented system that integrates the nominal model and the disturbance model. In the design of an offset-free MPC, the work presented in Cao, Son, Moon, and Kwon (2021) could serve as a helpful reference. 4. Conclusion In conclusion, this study successfully demonstrated the effectiveness of integrating the three machine learning paradigms (unsupervised, supervised, and reinforcement learning) with model predictive control and multi-agent principles to design a precise irrigation scheduler for large-scale fields. By employing a three-stage process with the k-means clustering approach, irrigation management zones were accurately delineated to match the resolution of the irrigation equipment. This process included elevation and estimated soil hydraulic parameters as attributes, resulting in optimized management zones suitable for agro-hydrological modeling. Leveraging the universal approximation capability of neural networks, specifically long short-term memory models, this study directly modeled the dynamic behavior of root zone soil moisture content in each irrigation management zone, while accounting for the time varying nature of the rooting depth. Based on the developed data-driven models, a mixed-integer MPC framework with zone objectives was designed to determine the daily irrigation decisions and rates, aiming to enhance soil water uptake while minimizing overall water consumption and associated irrigation costs. Furthermore, a multi-agent MPC paradigm was adopted where decentralized hybrid actor–critic agents and the concept of a limiting management zone were employed to enhance the computational efficiency of the scheduler. The application of the proposed approach to a large-scale field demonstrated its capability to achieve substantial water savings and improved irrigation water use efficiency. The proposed approach also allowed for the utilization of less conservative MAD values, resulting in improved water savings and optimal crop growth. While the proposed approach shows promise, there are several modifications that can be made to further enhance its effectiveness. One priority is improving the optimality of the binding irrigation decision sequence by employing distributed techniques when training the hybrid actor–critic agents. Utilizing a hierarchy of agents that communicate with each other can result in an irrigation decision sequence that is optimal for all the management zones of the field. Additionally, this study acknowledges the potential advantages of integrating advanced time-series transformer models, as indicated in recent literature (Sitapure & Kwon, 2023). These transformer models are recognized for their proficiency in capturing complex contextual relationships, including faults, abnormalities, and parametric dependencies. While the current study employs LSTM models, considering the replacement of the LSTM approach with advanced time-series transformer models is considered a promising avenue for enhancing predictive capabilities in irrigation scheduling. Furthermore, to enhance the overall robustness of the scheduler, it is advisable to implement it alongside a lower-level controller. This controller’s task would be to track the prescriptions made by the proposed scheduler on an hourly basis. By integrating these components, the scheduler can adapt and respond in real-time to deviations or unforeseen circumstances, ensuring effective irrigation management. Implementing these modifications will contribute to the continued improvement and practical application of the scheduler, making it more effective and reliable in optimizing irrigation decisions while maintaining system robustness. Paper 5:
- APA Citation: Stringam, B. L. (2010). Design of a Single-Pool Downstream Controller Using Quantitative Feedback Control Theory. Journal of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering, 136(10), 112-118. https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)IR.1943-4774.0000222
  Main Objective: To design and test a downstream controller for an irrigation canal system using quantitative feedback control theory (QFT).
  Study Location: Unspecified
  Data Sources: Nonlinear model that numerically solves the St. Venant equations
  Technologies Used: QFT, PID control, LQR control
  Key Findings: 1. The QFT controller outperforms the PID and LQR controllers in terms of stability and response time.
    2. The QFT controller is able to handle uncertainties and time-varying parameters, making it suitable for canal control where conditions can vary significantly.
    3. QFT is a promising technique for the design of robust and reliable controllers for automated irrigation systems.
  Extract 1: "A downstream controller is designed for an irrigation canal reach using a design technique called quantitative feedback control theory (QFT)."
  Extract 2: "The performance of this controller is compared to a proportional, integral, derivative (PID) controller and a linear quadratic regulator (LQR) controller. In this study, the QFT controller is designed for a single canal reach because it best demonstrates how a controller is designed."
  Limitations: None
  Relevance Evaluation: This paper is highly relevant to the point of implementing feedback loops for automated irrigation systems because it provides a detailed explanation of the design and implementation of a QFT-based downstream controller for an irrigation canal. The paper discusses the advantages of QFT, such as its ability to handle uncertainties and time-varying parameters, and presents a step-by-step design process for a QFT controller. The paper also includes simulation results comparing the performance of the QFT controller to a PID controller and an LQR controller, showing that the QFT controller has better performance in terms of stability and response time.
  Relevance Score: 0.9
  Inline Citation: (Stringam, 2010)
  Explanation: Stringam's research focuses on the design of a downstream controller for an irrigation canal system using quantitative feedback control theory (QFT). QFT allows for the development of robust and stable controllers that can handle system uncertainties and time-varying parameters, making it suitable for canal control where conditions can vary significantly.

Stringam blairs@nmsu.eduAUTHOR AFFILIATIONS Publication: Journal of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering Volume 136, Issue 10 https://doi.org/10.1061/(ASCE)IR.1943-4774.0000222 112 PDF Journal of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering Volume 136, Issue 10 October 2010 Abstract Introduction Results Conclusions References Information & Authors Metrics & Citations References Media Tables Share Abstract A downstream controller is designed for an irrigation canal reach using a design technique called quantitative feedback control theory (QFT). The performance of this controller is compared to a proportional, integral, derivative (PID) controller and a linear quadratic regulator (LQR) controller. In this study, the QFT controller is designed for a single canal reach because it best demonstrates how a controller is designed. Previous research for this canal model provided data for comparison. For the operating conditions that are defined in this paper, the QFT controller is shown to have slightly better performance than the PID controller and better performance than the LQR controller. When the canal hydraulic roughness is increased, the QFT controller still performed better than the PID controller. Introduction Throughout the world, there is an increasing demand for fresh water. As rural, environmental, and urban demands increase, new approaches must be investigated to stretch the limited water supply. In some areas, people have limited water allocations and they have learned to conserve and achieve the greatest benefit from a limited supply. Through improved knowledge and skills, farmers with limited water supplies have improved crop yields. As farmers’ knowledge and skill improve, more timely and accurate water deliveries are required. Water supply companies and irrigation districts are also learning to conserve water through improved management methods. In some cases, water is conserved by upgrading the delivery system, while in other cases, water is conserved by automating existing canal gates (Walker and Stringam 1999). This paper discusses the design and testing of a downstream controller for a single reach (local controller). This controller is designed using a technique called quantitative feedback control theory (QFT). The controller is designed for a single reach because it serves as an example that best explains the design methods. This paper does not use the multiple reach examples defined by the ASCE test cases (Clemmens et al. 1998) because these cases are for multiple reaches in series. The QFT method is demonstrated for a canal model that is reported by Reddy (1990). This model is used because data are provided to make comparisons. A description of a QFT design for a single reach is required before a multireach design can be explained. QFT controllers can be designed to operate multiple reaches (global system or global controller) but the basic design techniques have to first be explained for a single reach. A global QFT controller will be reported in a subsequent paper. Background On the majority of canal systems, flow rates and water control depths are varied throughout the irrigation season. In addition, canal hydraulic parameters change over time. In control terms, the system is time varying. This is especially true for earthen canals because weeds grow throughout the year, embankments degrade, sediment collects in various places, and seepage changes throughout the season. Even concrete-lined canals experience changes (Rogers 1997). In addition, it is virtually impossible to determine exact canal parameters for many earthen canals. If the canal was constructed several years ago, the original design specifications may have been lost or misplaced. Even if the specifications were available, the canal system is not likely to be in the same condition as the day it was constructed. For these reasons, a control system that operates optimally must be sensitive to changes in canal system parameters and handle varied operational control-depth set points. The various automation methods that have been developed for canal automation are diverse in their design and implementation. The control methods that have been studied may be categorized into three areas: process control, heuristic control, and analytical methods. A simple mathematical model that simulates canal hydraulics may be used in process control design. However, canal hydraulics can be difficult to accurately model. This is especially true with earthen canals. Heuristic Control Heuristic methods (trial and error designs coupled with canal operations experience) were developed because of the difficulty of deriving an accurate canal model. Examples of heuristic canal controllers are the CARDD (Burt 1983), BIVAL (Chevereau and Schwartz-Benezeth 1987), and UMA (UMA Engineering Ltd. 1989) methods. Parrish (1994) proposed a method similar to the UMA and CARDD methods. Analytical Control Analytical methods develop control algorithms based on hydraulic equations. Technically, the analytical methods described by Wylie (1969), Falvey and Luning (1979), and Liu et al. (1992) are feed-forward methods. Even though this paper describes a downstream feedback controller, the feed forward control method is mentioned because the desired outcome is to control a downstream water level. Process Control Methods Several process control methods have been developed over the past 50 years. The most prevalent and successful is proportional, integral, derivative (PID) control. This method is a subclass of the frequency design control method (Dorf 1992; Phillips and Harbor 1991; and Stephanopoulos 1984). PID control has demonstrated a great degree of robustness in many applications. It is used extensively in industrial applications because of its robust nature. The Laplace form (Phillips and Harbor 1991) of this control equation is shown below G ( s ) = K d s 2 + K p s + K i s (1) where G ( s ) represents the controller or compensator transfer function; K p = proportional gain; K i = integral gain; K d = derivative gain; and s = Laplace operator term. A control algorithm may include all three components or some of these components. The majority of downstream controllers do not use the derivative component because it is hard to tune for long time delays. This controller can be designed/tuned using a system model equation and frequency design techniques. A controller can also be developed using an empirical design method such as the Ziegler-Nichols tuning method (Stephanopoulos 1984). El-Flo (Ploss 1987) used a simplified form of the PID controller where the derivative component is not used, but the proportional component and, to some extent, the integral component are used. Wahlin and Clemmens (2002) also used a proportional integral (PI) controller to operate a series of canal reaches. The PI controller was tuned by trial and error for one reach, then an additional reach was added to the system and the system was retuned. Wahlin (2004) developed a downstream controller with a feed-forward component. Litrico and Fromion (2006) used an analytical design method to develop a downstream PI controller. The PID equation has an additional “ s ” term [Eq. (1)] in the numerator, indicating that there is an excess of zeros (numerator roots) over poles (denominator roots). Thus, there is a potential for instability. A stable controller design will have equal poles and zeros or more poles than zeros. This makes tuning or selecting gains very important because poorly selected gains can create a controller that has ranges of instability. Often, systems exhibit varied responses throughout the entire operation range and multiple gains or gain scheduling (Stephanopoulos 1984) may be needed. State-space design is another process control method that has been used to develop canal controllers (Balogun et al. 1988; Reddy 1990; Clemmens et al. 1997; Schuurmans 1997). Reddy (1990) developed a single pool controller while the other researchers focused on multireach control systems. Reddy used linear quadratic regulator (LQR) theory to design the controller for a single research. State-space methods require a reasonable system model for controller design. Defining a reasonable model is as difficult for state-space design as it is for frequency design control methods. The system model must be linearized and often simplified to determine the required control gains. In the case of a canal system, the control routine requires a linearized system for one control depth, roughness, and flow rate. If any of these parameters change significantly, a new set of gains is required to optimally control the canal gates. This problem can be dealt with using a technique called gain scheduling, but this technique can be complicated and difficult to properly program into the control code (Stephanopoulos 1984). QFT A process control method termed QFT can be used to design control algorithms for systems that have uncertain or time-varying parameters (Horowitz 1993). QFT is a frequency design control method that is used to develop a feedback controller/compensator. This design method incorporates differential, integral, and proportional control components similar to PID, but these components are balanced to insure stability. This method was developed with the understanding that it is impossible to develop a mathematical relationship that exactly models a real system. This design method can be used to design a canal controller, but the variability in canal parameters must be determined for the entire operational range. These parameters are then used to construct a design region/boundary on a Nichols chart (Horowitz 1993). If the designer does not cross this boundary, the controller is guaranteed to be stable through the entire operation range. System Model QFT requires a system model or extensive testing to determine the design boundary. Schuurmans (1997) conducted extensive research to develop a simplified process model that can be used for canal controller design. The model is simpler than the St. Venant equations and takes the following form: P u ( s ) = e − T s A s (2) where P u ( s ) = variable that represents the “plant” or in this case the canal; e − T s = time -delay function; T = time delay (s); A = surface area of the backwater curve ( m 2 ) ; and s = Laplace operator. Schuurmans et al. (1999) described how values can be determined for A and T . Canal Model The canal dimensions that are used to design a downstream controller were taken from Reddy (1990). Reddy used a state-space method to design a local downstream controller. The canal has a length of 5,000 m, a longitudinal channel slope of 0.0003, a side slope of 1.0, a bottom width of 1.70 m, a Manning roughness of 0.016, an upstream reservoir elevation of 103.2 m, a downstream reservoir elevation of 101.14 m, an upstream canal invert of 102 m, a downstream canal invert of 99.94 m, and a downstream target depth of 1.2 m. The canal model is initially operated with a constant flow rate of 3.02 m 3 / s . The turnout flow at the end of this canal is 2.50 m 3 / s and the flow at the end of the canal is 0.52 m 3 / s . QFT Controller Design While QFT can be used to design a global control system, the design of a local controller must first be understood. The remainder of this paper will describe the design of a local downstream controller for a single canal reach. A nonlinear model that numerically solves the St. Venant equations (Stringam 1998) was used to develop model parameters for A and T . The values were determined using a method described by Schuurmans (1997). Values ranging from 9,197 to 9,290 m 2 were obtained for A and 1,200–1,300 s for T . These values where inserted into Eq. (2) and the frequency response of each equation was plotted on a Bode plot (Fig. 1). From the values for area and time, crossover frequencies of 1.01 × 10 − 5 and 9.09 × 10 − 6 rad / s were measured on a Bode plot (Fig. 1). Fig. 1. Bode plot for A = 9 , 120 m 2 and T = 1 , 300 s This plot is obtained by placing a range of frequencies into the model equation and the resulting values are placed on the Bode plot. The point where the plot of the system equation model crosses over the 0-dB line on the Bode plot is termed the crossover frequency (Dorf 1992). This is a critical point because this is where the closed loop canal model is likely to pass from an unstable condition to a stable one. The values for A , T , and a crossover frequency of 1.01 × 10 − 5 rad / s were used to calculate phase values ranging from −90.752° to −90.694° and magnitude values from 20.55 to 20.64 dB. These values are determined by first converting the “ s ” term of Eq. (2) into corresponding imaginary and frequency components P ( j ω ) = e − j ω T A j ω (3) where j = imaginary number and ω = crossover frequency in rad/s. This equation can be broken up into magnitude and phase components as follows: | P ( j ω ) | = 1 A ω ; ∠ P ( j ω ) = ( − ω T − π / 2 ) (4) One of the magnitude values was generated as follows: | P ( j ω ) | = 1 A ω = 1 9197 ⋅ 1.01 × 10 − 5 = 10.765 (5) This value is converted to dB in order to locate a point on the Nichols chart (Fig. 2) 20 ⋅ log ( 10.765 ) = 20.64 dB (6) The corresponding phase angle is determined through the following relationship: ∠ P ( j ω ) = ( − ω T − π / 2 ) = ( − 1.01 × 10 − 5 ⋅ 1200 − π / 2 ) = − 1.58 rads / s (7) The value is converted to degrees by performing the following operation: − 1.58 rads / s ( 180 π ) = − 90.692 ° (8) A detailed explanation of how these values are determined can be found in Houpis and Rasmussen (1999). The angles and magnitudes are used to define corners of a design template (Fig. 2). The values for magnitude and phase that were generated for the values of A and T are shown in Table 1. Once the values for all four corners are determined, a template can be plotted as shown in Fig. 2. This template defines a region of uncertainty because the canal parameters cannot be defined exactly. If the true canal parameters were known and the parameters did not vary, the template would be defined by a dot and not an area. All of the numbers that have been determined so far have been for a frequency of 1.01 × 10 − 5 rad / s . These are the numbers that are used to design the template in Fig. 2. A template was also constructed for the 9.09 × 10 − 6 rad / s frequency, but it was smaller than the template in Fig. 2. The worst-case scenario occurs for a frequency of 1.01 × 10 − 5 rad / s . Controller design is continued for the 1.01 × 10 − 5 rad / s frequency because this is the worst case and will help to develop a more robust design. Fig. 2. Nichols plot showing system or “plant” template. The template is small for this example so it is magnified to show the template shape. Table 1. Magnitude and Phase Angles That Were Generated Using a Crossover Frequency of 1.01 × 10 − 5 rad / s ; These Values Were Used to Construct a Template Backwater curve surface area ( m 2 ) Delay time(s) Magnitude(dB) Phase 9,197 1,200 20.64 −90.694° 9,197 1,300 20.64 −90.752° 9,290 1,200 20.55 −90.694° 9,290 1,300 20.55 −90.752° Once the template is constructed, it can be moved to the 3 dB contour. This template is then slid around the 3 dB contour (Houpis and Rasmussen 1999) on a Nichols chart (Fig. 3). The template has been duplicated at several positions around the 3-dB contour to illustrate how the template is slid around the contour. The template is also smaller in Fig. 3 because the scale of the chart has changed. The 3-dB contour is used because Horowitz (1993) has determined that if the system model plus the feedback controller can operate outside this contour, the system will be stable. The template must have the same vertical and horizontal orientations as it is moved all the way around the 3-dB contour (Fig. 3). As the template is slid around the 3-dB contour, a point of the template boundary should always touch the 3-dB contour, but the template cannot cross the contour. The contour is drawn by placing a pen in the corner of the template and tracing a boundary line. The corner in this design corresponds to a value of 1,300 s for T and 9 , 290 m 2 for A or the corresponding 20.55 dB and −90.752°. This point is at the lower left corner of the template. This corner is selected for convenience and ease of plotting, but any other corner could be selected provided the template does not cross the 3 dB boundary. By using the template in this manner, the variability of system parameters is taken into account in the resulting boundary. This boundary is called the “U-contour.” The right side of the U contour follows the 3-dB contour because the point of the pen and the corner of the template touch the contour. As the template is slid around the 3-dB contour, the template boundary forces the pen away from the 3-db contour on the bottom and to the left of the diagram. The U contour that is constructed with this template accounts for the variability in crossover frequency and the variability in A and T . If these parameters were exactly known, the U contour would be traced on the 3 dB contour. It should be noted that in most QFT designs, the U contour is shaped like the letter U. However, in this design, the shape is more oval in shape. Fig. 3. Nichols plot showing the U contour drawn using the system template. The template is drawn in multiple points around the 3-dB contour to demonstrate how it is slide around the contour without crossing the contour. Once the contour has been traced, the uncompensated system response is plotted on the Nichols chart (Fig. 4). Uncompensated means that there is no feedback controller that is trying to influence or change the system response. This plot is determined by entering multiple frequencies into to the model and measuring the change in phase and magnitude outputs from the model. These values are generated using Eqs. (5) - (8) for each frequency input. As the values are determined, they are plotted on the Nichols chart. The plot of the uncompensated model shows that it must be pulled closer to the U-contour. If plot of the model response can be pulled closer to the contour, it means that the model will respond faster to control changes. This is accomplished by adding an “ s ” term to the denominator of the system compensator (adding lag). This pulls the system to the left and closer to the U contour. The 75-dB point is selected as an appropriate place to start. This point is selected because it provides ample opportunity to pull the system response plot to the left and closer to the contour. The 75-dB point has a corresponding frequency of 2 × 10 − 8 rad / s . This frequency is determined by locating the 75-dB point on the Bode plot in Fig. 1 and finding the corresponding frequency for that point. The inverse of this frequency is determined to be 5 × 10 7 . This value is placed in the denominator (adding lag) of the controller/compensator equation G ( s ) = 1 5 × 10 7 s + 1 (9) The result is plotted as the dashed line (canal model with lag) in Fig. 4. This plot shows that the additional lag is forcing the system through the U contour. The goal of this design is to force the canal model close to the U contour without crossing the contour boundaries. As the design progresses, the canal model plus the compensator response will be forced around the right side of the U contour. The Nichols chart shows that the U contour reaches a maximum point on the right side of about −135°. The plot of the system response should be forced to the right to about −135° to obtain a good design. Fig. 4. Nichols chart showing the U contour and the system response with various compensator design stages If an s term is added to the numerator (adding lead) of the compensator, the system is pulled to the right. By studying the plot of the canal model with lag in Fig. 4, it was determined that the system response curve can be pulled to the right if lead is added in the −100- to −105-dB range. This range is used because this is where the plot of the system response curve bends more drastically to the left. In order to continue with this design, the −102-dB point is selected. The Bode plot of the canal model with lag in Fig. 5 indicates that a frequency of 5.4 × 10 − 4 rad / s corresponds to the −102-dB value. The resulting compensator equation is G ( s ) = 1 , 852 s + 1 5 × 10 7 s + 1 (10) The canal model plus the lead and lag compensator response is plotted as a dotted line in Fig. 4. The plot shows that it is not far enough to the right because the bend in the curve does not reach to the −135° point. Additional lead needs to be added to the compensator. The bend in the plot of the canal model with lead and lag in Fig. 4 is the best region to determine a value for additional lead. This region starts at about −110 dB and ends at about −125 dB. Selecting a frequency for the −110-dB point would pull the system response to the right, but it would be pulled too far to the right. The −115-dB value is selected with a corresponding frequency of 7.0 × 10 − 4 rad / s . This frequency is again determined by creating a Bode plot of the canal model with the lead and lag compensator and finding the frequency that corresponds to the −115-dB point. This plot has been omitted because it is similar to Fig. 5 and the procedure is the same for all Bode plots. Lead is added to the compensator and the resulting equation is G ( s ) = 2.65 × 10 6 s 2 + 3 , 281 s + 1 5 × 10 7 s + 1 (11) The result is the plot of the dot-dashed line (additional lead added to the model and compensator). A gain must be added to the canal model and compensator to push the response up to the U contour. This is accomplished by adding a gain of 900,000 to the compensator. The value was determined by measuring the difference in dB between the bottom of the U contour and the horizontal portion of the plot of the compensator with additional lead line in Fig. 4. This difference was determined to be 119 dB. If Eq. (6) is solved backward, the following value is determined: gain = 10 119 / 20 ≈ 900 , 000 (12) Fig. 6 shows the plot of the system response with the compensator. More “zeros” and “poles” could be added to push the response closer to the U contour, but this paper focuses on the design process, which has been sufficiently demonstrated at this point. Presently, the compensator has an excess of “zeros” over “poles” and a system instability may exist. This is corrected by added lag at a frequency of 1.0 × 10 − 2 rad / s . This balances the poles and the zeros and helps make the compensator more stable. The addition of this pole has a small effect on the system and the resulting plot follows the same line as the previous compensator. Fig. 5. Bode plot for the canal model and the initial compensator of G ( s ) = 1 / ( 5 × 10 7 s + 1 ) . A frequency of 5.4 × 10 − 4 rads / s is read from the magnitude plot at about −102 dB. Fig. 6. Nichols plot showing the system response with the compensator in relationship to the U contour The resulting compensator in Laplace form is presented below: G ( s ) = 2.38 × 10 12 s 2 + 2.95 × 10 9 s + 9.0 × 10 5 5 × 10 9 s 2 + 5 × 10 7 s + 1 (13) The system model and compensator cross the U-contour, but this line is still close to the outside of the contour. In some cases, there may be a concern with this type of design, but test results below indicate that the compensator accomplishes the desired response. The Laplace form of this equation is hard to implement in a feedback control computer program. The equation must be converted to a digital form. If a control interval of 1 min is used, the compensator equation takes the following form: Δ q k = 1.549 Δ q k − 1 − 0.5488 Δ q k − 2 + 47.17 e k − 91.68 e k − 1 + 44.56 e k − 2 (14) where Δ q k represents the flow rate change; Δ q k − 1 represents the last flow rate change; Δ q k − 2 represents the flow rate change prior to the last flow rate change; e k = difference between the water level set point and the present water level; e k − 1 is the last error that was measured between the set point and the water level; and e k − 2 = error that was measured prior to the last error. The method that is used to convert the Laplace compensator equation to the digital compensator equation can be found in Dorf (1992). The above equation is in the form that could be implemented in a computer control unit that is located at the canal gate control site. The equation indicates that the last two gate flow rate changes and the last two errors would have to be remembered in order to compute the required flow change. As indicated earlier, the control interval was 1 min, however, a control engineer may select an interval of 5 or 10 min. If this were true, the gains that are indicated in Eq. (13) would change. The controller/compensator has been designed considering the variations of the canal parameters. If all variations in system parameters are accounted for in the original template, the resulting controller will be stable. This is true even if the system parameters change, provided that the variations were accounted for in the original template. Results The previously designed QFT controller was tested on a nonlinear model (Stringam 1998) with the dimensions defined by Reddy (1990). Considering that the goal of designing a compensator is to control a canal, a nonlinear model that solves the St. Venant equations would give a more realistic response. A PID controller was also designed to control this nonlinear model using the Ziegler-Nichols tuning method (Stephanopoulos 1984). The PID controller is used for comparison because there are differential, integral, and proportional components contained within the QFT compensator design. The results from these two controllers were compared to one of the tests for the LQR controller reported by Reddy (1990) where an additional flow rate of 0.25 m 3 / s is taken at the downstream end of the reach. This would tend to bias the results toward the LQR controller because it was tested on a linear model. The results of all three controllers can be observed in Fig. 7. This graph shows the resulting downstream depths when the outflow is increased. Fig. 7. Plot of the downstream depth for the QFT, PID, and LQR controllers. A flow rate of 0.25 m 3 / s is taken at the downstream end of the reach. The graph of the response of all three methods indicates that the PID method and the QFT method have similar responses. It may be difficult to argue that one method is better than the other, except that the QFT method has less overshoot and settles into the set point sooner. Fig. 7 indicates that the LQR controller does not bring the system back to the set point as quickly as the PID and QFT methods. In addition, after the system reaches its minimum, the LQR controller has a slower initial rate of recovery than the other two controllers. A final test was conducted by changing the channel roughness from 0.016 to 0.019. All the other parameters, which were previously defined, were kept the same. The demand at the downstream end of the reach was increased an additional 0.25 m 3 / s . Fig. 8 shows that the PID controller had more of an oscillatory response than the QFT controller. Though the QFT method had more overshoot than the previous test, it was less than the PID method. The QFT controller again settled into the set point sooner. Fig. 8. Plot of the downstream depth for the QFT and PID controllers. An additional flow rate of 0.25 m 3 / s is taken at the downstream end of the reach. The canal roughness has been increased to 0.019. Conclusions It could be argued that there is little advantage of a QFT controller over a PID controller. The results of this paper indicate that both methods have similar responses. However, there are several factors that should be considered before drawing this conclusion. First, the PID controller equation has an excess of s terms in the numerator. This means that there is the possibility of instability in the control system. Experienced control engineers and technicians will often say that they have had instances where seemingly stable PID controllers suddenly became unstable and the controller had to be shut down before there were disastrous results (Phillips and Harbor 1991). An additional concern is the fact that PID controllers have narrower operational ranges than QFT controllers. This can be corrected with gain scheduling (Stephanopoulos 1984), but this makes the controller code more complicated than QFT controller code. As mentioned previously, canals are operated at different levels, weeds grow in the canal, silt collects, and seepage changes throughout the irrigation season. A QFT controller can be designed with a wider operation range to account for these changes. This wider range was demonstrated in Fig. 8. When the results from the PID and QFT controller were compared to the LQR controller, they performed better than the LQR method. In this case, the LQR controller had a slower response than the PID and QFT controllers. The final and most important reason for considering QFT is that it can be applied to global control systems. A controller for a canal system seldom functions well if it is made up of several local controllers. On the other hand, a global controller will minimize the interference that the different reaches have on each other and arrive at the control solution that will best operate the entire system. A global QFT controller will be reported in a subsequent paper. References Balogun, O. S., Hubbard, M., and DeVries, J. J.   Main Objective: To evaluate the current state and future potential of end-to-end automated irrigation management systems that integrate Internet of Things (IoT) and machine learning technologies, with a focus on exploring automation across the entire pipeline, emphasizing interoperability and standardization, identifying challenges, and proposing solutions.

  Key Findings: - Model-based control strategies potentially avoid the limitations of sensor-based irrigation strategies by using a crop and/or soil production model to make decisions on water application and/or timing.

- The MPC strategy was successfully implemented in VARIwise and performed well in controlling an automatic irrigation machine applying spatially-varied irrigation amounts in simulated cotton crop scenarios.

- The MPC strategy can be used to optimize crop yield, crop water use efficiency, or irrigation water use efficiency, as appropriate, based on the user-specified objective.

- The MPC strategy produced significantly higher yield and crop water use efficiency than sensor-based strategies for the same simulated field conditions, but required more comprehensive data input for accurate crop model calibration.
